event.title: Graduate Commencement
event.shortdesc: Graduate Commencement Ceremony

p.span: For the first time, there will be a separate commencement ceremony held for graduate degree candidates on May 7. The May 7 commencement ceremony for master's degree and/or post-bachelor's teacher certification will be held in Pucillo Gymnasium at 6:30 p.m. featuring Tiffany Wright, Ed.D., ‘02M, as the commencement ceremony speaker.

Wright is the Career Academy principal at York County School of Technology in York, Pa. She received a bachelor's degree from Gettysburg College and earned a master's degree in leadership in teaching and learning at Millersville University. In 2009, she completed her doctoral program at Johns Hopkins University and was presented the prestigious 2009-2010 Phi Delta Kappa International Outstanding Doctoral Dissertation Award.

fulldesc.span: For more information regarding the May 2010 commencements please go to Millersville's commencement website at www.millersville.edu/commencement/index.php.

event.title: Trevor Hershey Exhibit
event.shortdesc: Trevor Hershey's Exhibit, Looking Back: Moving Forward, explores issues of civilization and expressions of life, home, death and the Earth.

fulldesc.p: Trevor Hershey's exhibit, Looking Back: Moving Forward, explores issues of civilization and expressions of life, home, death and the earth. The exhibit runs until February 25.

Trevor Hershey is an art teacher at Ephrata High School where he teaches painting, clay and design. His artwork is a combination of aboriginal Australian artwork, abstract expressionism, maps, primitivism, and symbolism.
Hershey's work allows him to explore issues of civilization as it becomes more and more separated from the web of life. The exhibit will include acrylic paintings on canvas, lithographs, clay sculpture, earthenware plates and works from handmade paper.

event.title: MLK Jr. Day of Service
event.shortdesc: MU students can register to participate in service projects in the Lancaster Community to honor the memory of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

fulldesc.p:
The Office of Internships and Civic Engagement Services, Volunteer Central, is proud to announce their plans to celebrate Martin Luther King Jr. Day of Service occurring on Monday, Jan. 18, 2010.
Although this event takes place the Monday before classes begin for the Spring Semester, we would like the university community to know that our students, faculty and Staff will be taking part in A Day On, Not A Day Off.
Volunteers will report to the Student Memorial Center (SMC) Multi-Purpose room at 8:30am on Monday, January 18th. After a brief overview of the day's schedule, participants will be transported to non-profit agencies in Lancaster where they will spend the day working in our community.
Transportation and T-Shirts will be provided for all participants who register before Jan. 1.

event.title: Sun Young Kang Art Exhibit
event.shortdesc: Filtered Memories exhibit by Sun Young Kang.

fulldesc.p: Ganser Gallery presents Filtered Memories, an exhibition of recent work by Sun Young Kang, from Jan. 26- Feb. 25. On Thursday, February 25at 5 p.m. the artist will present a gallery talk. Both the exhibition and the talk are free and open to the public.

Filtered Memories consists of scrolls hung from the ceiling to create a sort of maze for the viewer. Kang used incense to write/burn excerpts from her father's diaries on to the scrolls. She explains: "Eight years after my father's death, my mother sent me his diaries which he began to write when he was my age. I have reproduced selections from those diaries. . . . This project gives my father's diary a new birth and let his voice be heard visually in a silence."
The exhibition also displays an array of the artist's awarding-winning handmade books.

Speaking generally about her work, Kang explains that "I cut out pages, burn out texts, hang prints in the space or cast various containers to create a physical and metaphorical emptiness in my work. The important parts of the structures are absent. The absence becomes a presence in the visual objects. . . . I would like the audience to think about the meaning of absence in our lives."

Ganser Gallery is located on the Millersville University campus, just off the lobby of the Ganser Libray. Gallery hours are Monday-Thursday 12 noon- 4:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. 9:00 p.m.; Friday, 12:00 noon- 4:00 p.m.; Sunday, 1:00-4:00 p.m. All Ganser Gallery events are free and open to the public.
Free tours of the exhibition may be scheduled by calling Ty Clever, gallery director: 717-871-2186. Email: tyler.clever@millersville.edu

event.title: The Sweetness of Charity: Haiti and Beyond
event.shortdesc: Reflect & Connect will meet to talk about charity both in our own community and abroad. The text will be Maya Angelou's "The Sweetness of Charity."

fulldesc.p:
Reflect & Connect will be meeting next Wednesday January 27th at 5 pm in Ford Atrium to talk about charity both in our own community and abroad. Volunteer Central will be there after the meeting to sign up anyone wanting to volunteer locally for the Haiti relief effort or other community efforts.
Please RSVP to Facebook or to 872-3049 so that we can plan the food.
The text will be Maya Angelou's "The Sweetness of Charity," - posted below.
The Sweetness of Charity
The New Testament informs the reader that it is more blessed to give than to receive. I have found that among its other benefits, giving liberates the soul of the giver. The size and substance of the gift should be important to the recipient, but not to the donor, save that the best thing one can give is that which is appreciated. The giver is as enriched as is the recipient, and more important, that intangible but very real psychic force of good in the world is increased.
When we cast our bread upon the waters, we can presume that someone downstream whose face we will never know will benefit from our action, as we who are downstream from another will profit from that grantor's gift.
Since time is the one immaterial object which we cannot influence -neither speed up nor slow down, add to nor diminish - it is an imponderably valuable gift. Each of us has a few minutes a day or a few hours a week which we could donate to an old folks' home or a children's hospital ward. The elderly whose pillows we plump or whose water pitchers we refill may or may not thank us for our gift, but the gift is upholding the foundation of the universe. The children to whom we read simple stories may or may not show gratitude, but each boon we give strengthens the pillars of the world.
While our gifts and the recipients should be considered, our bounty, once decided upon, should be without concern, overflowing one minute and forgotten the next.
Recently I was asked to speak before a group of philanthropists and was astonished at their self-consciousness. The gathered donors give tens of millions of dollars annually to medical research, educational development, art support, and social reform. Yet to a person they seemed a little, just a little, ashamed of themselves. I pondered their behavior and realized that someone had told someone that not only was it degrading to accept charity but it was equally debasing to give it. And sad to say, someone had believed that statement. Hence ,many preferred to have it known that they dispense philanthropy rather than charity.
I like charitable people and like to think of myself as charitable, as being of a generous heart and a giving nature - of being a friend indeed to anyone in need. Why, I pondered, did the benefactors not feel as I?
Some benefactors may desire distance from the recipients of their largess because there is a separation between themselves and the resources they distribute. As inheritors or managers of fortune rather than direct earners, perhaps they feel exiled from the gifts; then it follows that they feel exiled from the recipient.
It is sad when people who give to the needy feel estranged from the objects of their generosity. They can take little, if any, relish from their acts of charity; therefore, [they] are generous out of their duty rather than delight.
If we change the way we think of charity, our personal lives will be richer and the larger world will be improved. When we give cheerfully and accept gracefully, everyone is blessed. "Charity...is kind;.... envieth not; ..vaunteth not itself; is not puffed up."

event.title: Martin Luther King Jr. Day with Dr. Cornel West
event.shortdesc: Dr. Cornel West will be speaking as part of Martin Luther King, Jr. Day events at Millersville.

fulldesc.p: Dr. Cornel West will be speaking as part of Martin Luther King, Jr. Day events at Millersville.

West is known as one of America's most provocative public intellectuals who has been a champion for racial justice since childhood. He appeared on the national scene in 1993 with his bestselling book, Race Matters, a searing analysis of racism in American democracy. He is an American philosopher, author, critic, pastor and civil rights activist. Dr. West currently teaches in the Center for African American Studies at Princeton University.
This event is sponsored by the NAACP, BSU, Commission on Cultural Diversity, Office of the President, Black Culture Celebration.
No tickets are required for this event.

link.name: Wikipedia's Entry of Dr. Cornel West

event.title: Church, Law and Society in the Middle Ages
event.shortdesc: Millersville's history department will host a conference, "Church, Law and Society in the Middle Ages."

p.span: On January 29-30 a oonference is scheduled at Millersville in honor of Prof. Peter Landau of the University of Munich. The conference, hosted by the Department of History at Millersville University, is a gathering of members of
- and others who have been influenced by Prof. Landau's work.

Papers are being presented by scholars from Europe, Japan and the USA, including Uta-Renata Blumenthal of the Catholic University of America, Bruce Brasington of West Texas A&M University, Tatsushi Genka of the University of Tokyo (Japan), Richard Helmholz of the University of Chicago, Thomas Izbicki of Rutgers University, John Lomax of Ohio Northern University, Thomas Morrissey of the State University of New York at Fredonia, Frederik Pedersen of the University of Aberdeen (Scotland), Mary Sommar of Millersville University, Brian Tierney of Cornell University, and Anders Winroth of Yale University.
This conference is sponsored by the

and the history department, the Phi Alpha Theta History student honor society,the Department of Government and Political Affairs, the Honors College, and the School of Humanities and Social Sciences at Millersville University.

All paper sessions will be held in the Bolger Conference Center in Gordinier Hall. Registration is $20.00 in advance or $25.00 (cash or check) at the door. For registration information contact Dr. Mary Sommar of the history department at msommar@millersville.edu.

For the Millersville University academic community sessions are open free of charge, but those who wish to make a reservation for the luncheon ($16.00 per person) should contact the history department.

event.title: Lecture: The Racialization of Latinos
event.shortdesc: Latino Celebration: The Racialization of Latinos with Dr. Salvador Vidal-Ortiz

fulldesc.p: Dr. Salvador Vidal-Ortiz is an assistant professor of sociology at American University. His academic interests range from U.S. race and ethnic studies, Puerto Rican/Latino studies, to sex/gender/sexuality scholarship, including transgender/transsexual studies and Queer Theory. Trained in a number of qualitative methods, he employs these for academic and community-based research/work. His grassroots-based experience includes HIV/AIDS prevention/services/community research, Latino queer organizing, progressive philanthropy, and program and organizational development.
No tickets are required for this event.

This event is sponsored by the Rosario Caminero Latino Celebration Committee, Latino/a Studies Minor, Society of Latino Affairs, Sociology/Anthropology Department, and the Office of Social Equity and Diversity.

event.title: Performance: "All Our Young Black Men Are Dying"
event.shortdesc: All Our Young Black Men Are Dying play. No tickets are required for this event

fulldesc.p: The play is a series of vignettes addressing issues facing young Black men in America. The topics are as relevant as today's headlines and as real as walking through any inner-city neighborhood. "Our Young Black Men" is much more than a play, it is an opportunity to discuss real issues facing contemporary American society. This historic and relevant performance will serve as a catalyst for meaningful dialogue and positive action. This non-confrontational play will serve as a useful aid to communities willing to address the topics the play raises. "Our Young Black Men Are Dying And Nobody Seems To Care" it's much more than a play, it is an experience!
This event is sponsored by the NAACP, Black Student Union, and Black Culture Celebration.

event.title: 2010 Red Dress Luncheon
event.shortdesc: 2010 Red Dress Luncheon for Women, featuring alumnus Jerri Anne Johnson '85.

fulldesc.p:
The 2010 Red Dress Luncheon for Women will feature alumnas Jerri Anne Johnson '76, '87 masters, director of the Women's Heart Health Initiative at Abbott Laboratories. Johnson will present, "Heart Disease in 2010: Is There a Difference between Men and Women?" Johnson received her undergraduate and graduate degrees from Millersville and spent the following 10 years teaching in the School District of Lancaster. For the past 20 years at Abbott, she held multiple positions before becoming director of the Women's Heart Health Initiative. In this role, Johnson develops educational programming for health care providers to improve their diagnosis and treatment of heart disease in women.
The luncheon costs $8 and participants must RSVP to Deb Miller at deb.miller@millersville.edu

event.title: V-Day 2010 Presents MMRP
event.shortdesc: V-Day Millersville 2010 presents a benefit performance of "A Memory, a Monologue, a Rant, and a Prayer"

fulldesc.p:
For the first time, V-Day Millersville 2010 will be presenting a special preview event, "A Memory, a Monologue, a Rant, and a Prayer" on February 5, 2010, in the Club de'Ville. This event is a performance of pieces by remarkable writers on the subject of violence against women. Admission is free with a suggested donation of $1.00 or a canned food item.
Performances of "The Vagina Monologues" and complementing events have raised millions of dollars for local charities over the past 10 years. At Millersville University, 2010 proceeds will benefit the Lancaster YWCA, an organization dedicated to eliminating racism, empowering women and promoting peace, justice, freedom and dignity for all.
Please visit www.vday.org for more information. These events are sponsored by the President's Commission on the Status of Women at Millersville University.

event.title: The Vagina Monologues
event.shortdesc: The Women's Commission at Millersville University presents two performances of Eve Ensler's play "The Vagina Monologues"

fulldesc.p:
The President's Commission on the Status of Women at Millersville University presents two performances of Eve Ensler's play "The Vagina Monologues" on February 12 & 13, 2010. Both performances begin at 8:00 p.m. and will be held in the Multipurpose Room of the Student Memorial Center on the Millersville University campus.
"The Vagina Monologues" has been performed on thousands of college and university campuses worldwide since 1998. Millersville University has been a participant since 2001, and this year's performance will feature dramatic sketches performed by women at MU. The performances are designed for both men and women, with the purpose of raising awareness about violence against women and girls.
Performances of "The Vagina Monologues" and complementing events have raised millions of dollars for local charities over the past 10 years. At Millersville University, 2010 proceeds will benefit the Lancaster YWCA, an organization dedicated to eliminating racism, empowering women and promoting peace, justice, freedom and dignity for all.
General admission tickets for "The Vagina Monologues" are $10.00 (pre-sale and at the door). MU students can buy tickets with ID for $5.00 pre-sale and $7.00 at the door. Tickets are available for purchase online at www.muticketsonline.com or by calling the Student Memorial Center Box Office at 717-872-3811, Monday through Friday, 8:00a.m. - 4:00p.m.
Please visit www.vday.org for more information. These events are sponsored by the President's Commission on the Status of Women at Millersville University.

event.title: Black Maria Film Screening
event.shortdesc: Third Annual Black Maria Film Screening - Informative discussion at noon, films at 1 p.m.

fulldesc.p:
Millersville University's third annual Black Maria film festival screenings are set to take place Feb. 13 and 14, 2010 in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall at 1 p.m. Since 1981, the annual Black Maria Film Video Festival, which takes its name from that of the world's first motion picture studio built by Thomas Edison in 1893, has been an international juried competition and award tour. The purpose of the Black Maria film festival is to advocate, exhibit and reward cutting edge works from independent film and video makers.
To deepen the appreciation of the Black Maria film festival and how modern film is presented, join Dr. Jill Craven, English, at noon on Saturday, Feb. 13 for an informative discussion prior to screening at 1 p.m.
Both the film screening and informative presentation are free and open to the public. Viewer discretion advised.
Black Maria (pronounced ma-RI-uh) Film and Video Festival is an independent nonprofit event that annually exhibits 50 new experimental, documentary, animation, and narrative works. The films are short (often just a few minutes long), and the festival typically runs for 90-110 minutes. From February to June each year, the festival tours throughout the US, and is shown at universities, arts organizations, and independent movie theaters. The festival has an international reputation, and is funded in part by the National Endowment for the Arts, the New Jersey Council on the Arts, the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation, and Eastman Kodak Corporation. Considered to be one of the best festivals of its kind, Black Maria Film Festival has been favorably reviewed by the New York Times and National Public Radio.

Millersville University's third annual Black Maria film festival screenings are set to take place Feb. 13 and 14, 2010 in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall at 1 p.m. Since 1981, the annual Black Maria Film Video Festival, which takes its name from that of the world's first motion picture studio built by Thomas Edison in 1893, has been an international juried competition and award tour. The purpose of the Black Maria film festival is to advocate, exhibit and reward cutting edge works from independent film and video makers.
To deepen the appreciation of the Black Maria film festival and how modern film is presented, join Caroline Savage, filmmaker and former Black Maria juror, at noon on Sunday, Feb. 14 for an informative discussion prior to screening at 1 p.m.
Both the film screening and informative presentation are free and open to the public. Viewer discretion advised.
Black Maria (pronounced ma-RI-uh) Film and Video Festival is an independent nonprofit event that annually exhibits 50 new experimental, documentary, animation, and narrative works. The films are short (often just a few minutes long), and the festival typically runs for 90-110 minutes. From February to June each year, the festival tours throughout the US, and is shown at universities, arts organizations, and independent movie theaters. The festival has an international reputation, and is funded in part by the National Endowment for the Arts, the New Jersey Council on the Arts, the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation, and Eastman Kodak Corporation. Considered to be one of the best festivals of its kind, Black Maria Film Festival has been favorably reviewed by the New York Times and National Public Radio.

event.shortdesc: A campus-wide rally to bring attention to Haiti will feature Haitian culture through dialogue, film and music.

event.title: Engaged Scholarship Workshop
event.shortdesc: ENGAGED SCHOLARSHIP WORKSHOP - presented by Trisha Thorme, Princeton University

p.span: Engaged Scholarship Workshop by Trisha Thorme will be given at 9:30 a.m. and 1 p.m.
This workshop will address such practicalities as how to generate and get community-based research and scholarship published.

Trisha Thorme serves as the assistant director for community-based learning at Princeton University. With Dean Peter Quimby, she administers the Community-Based Learning Initiative and is responsible for its daily operations. She facilitates community-based research and learning projects for faculty members, students and community organization leaders. She presents nationally on community-based research and scholarship. Along with several Millersville faculty members she will conduct workshops on creating publishable scholarship from community-based research. In addition to being a resource for publishing opportunities, she will meet one-on-one to see how your syllabus can become the basis for scholarly work.

event.title: CPEC Job Fair
event.shortdesc: CPEC Job Fair

fulldesc.p:
Central Pennsylvania Employment Consortium Job & Internship Fair (CPEC)
Radisson Penn-Harris Hotel & Convention Center
1150 Camp Hill Bypass, Camp Hill, Pennsylvania 17011
10:00am-3:00pm
Sponsored by CPEC College & University members and the Employer Advisory Board
Candidates who attend CPEC may be seeking full-time opportunities or internship positions. Participants represent over 60 majors, including fields of study ranging from liberal arts to professional programs.
CPEC draws 100+ employers annually from a wide variety of businesses and fields who are seeking to fill career and internship positions with the "best and brightest" candidates.
Candidates must be pursuing, or have completed, an associates, bachelors, or graduate degree program at a college or university.
If you are enrolled in, or have graduated from, one of the CPEC member colleges or universities, admission is free.
There is a $10 (CASH ONLY) charge for students and alumni of any college or university that is NOT a CPEC member school.
Because the fair is very busy, only candidates will be allowed into the employer area. It is strongly recommended that guests and children should not accompany candidates to the fair.
Be sure to bring many copies of your resume - one resume will be collected at the Registration Area.
Employers who are attending and other useful hints can be found at www.cpec.info:
Helpful Hints to Making the Most of CPEC
How to Prepare
Dress for Success
What to Expect
How to Approach a Recruiter
Online Applications
What to do After the Fair
Questions? Contact Career Services - 872-3312 or email castudent@millersville.edu.

event.title: Lecture: "Educating for Civic Responsibility" by Thomas Ehrlich
event.shortdesc: "EDUCATING FOR CIVIC RESPONSIBILITY: An Imperative for 21st Century Higher Education" by Thomas Ehrlich
event.fulldesc:
Thomas Ehrlich is a Senior Scholar at the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. Ehrlich served as president of Indiana University, provost of the University of Pennsylvania, and dean of Stanford Law School. He was also the first president of the Legal Services Corporation in Washington, D.C., and the first director of the International Development Cooperation Agency, reporting to President Carter. Before coming to the Carnegie Foundation, he was a Distinguished University Scholar at California State University and taught regularly at San Francisco State University. He is author, co-author, or editor of twelve books including Educating Citizens: Preparing Undergraduates for Lives of Moral and Civic Responsibility (2003), Reconnecting Education and Foundations: Turning Good Intentions into Educational Capital (2007), and Educating for Democracy: Preparing Undergraduates for Lives of Responsible Political Engagement (2007). He is a trustee of Mills College and has been a trustee of the University of Pennsylvania and Bennett College. He is a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School and holds five honorary degrees.
Sponsors of this event include Civic &Community Engagment & Research Project and the Offices of the Provost and the Vice President for Student Affairs.
This event is free and open to the public. No tickets are required to attend.

event.title: Marian Anderson String Quartet and Marian Anderson Historical Society
event.shortdesc: Marian Anderson String Quartet at Bright Side Baptist Church

fulldesc.p: The Marian Anderson String Quartet came together on September 30, 1989, as the Chamindale Quartet. The quartet's distinguished history includes performances through the Da Camera Society, the San Luis Obispo Mozart Festival and the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. Driven by their belief in the power of education, the Marian Anderson String Quartet has performed in hundreds of churches, libraries, museums, soup kitchens and prisons.

Blanche Burton-Lyles, the founder of the Marian Anderson Historical Society, will speak at this event. The Marian Anderson Historical Society was formed after Anderson's passing to continue her legacy by assisting and mentoring vocal classical artists in their professional careers. Also appearing, Dr. Lori Brown Mirabal, International opera singer, music educator, and parent.

No tickets are needed for this event. The performance is sponsored by Frederick Douglass Black Culture Celebration, University Honors College, Commission on Cultural Diversity, NAACP, Black Student Union and the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Sane: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Sane: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.

fulldesc.p: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest swept the 1975 Academy Awards, winning Best Film, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actor (Jack Nicholson), and Best Actress (Louise Fletcher). It's a film that deserves viewing on the big screen; it gets better with each viewing. And now you can see it in high definition!

Milos Forman's classic One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest stars Jack Nicholson as a rebel challenging institutional control over the individual. In the film R.P. McMurphy (Nicholson) tries to escape the rigors of prison by pretending to be insane; however, as he refuses to settle into the controlled life of the mental institution, his arch nemesis Nurse Ratched (Fletcher) begins to drive him really crazy.
It's free and open to the public. Post-screening discussion on Reframing Sanity led by Dr. Shawn Gallagher, Associate Professor of Psychology.
Sponsored by the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.

link.name: One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest

event.title: Lecture: Marian Anderson: The Sound of Freedom
event.shortdesc:
"Marian Anderson: The Sound of Freedom"
Presented by Ray Arsenault, PhD John Hope Franklin, Professor of History, USF
event.fulldesc:
The University Honors College and the Marian Anderson Celebration Committee invite the campus and community to attend “Marian Anderson: The Sound of Freedom,” a free public presentation that is part of the University’s Marian Anderson Celebration. Dr. Ray Arsenault, a prize-winning historian and biographer will address Ms. Anderson’s extraordinary and controversial career and her impact on American culture.
A specialist in Southern history and American race relations, Dr. Arsenault is the author of several prize-winning books, including the much acclaimed “Freedom Riders: 1961 and the Struggle for Racial Justice” (2006). In 2009 he published the celebrated biography “The Sound of Freedom: Marian Anderson’s Historic Concert at the Lincoln Memorial.” Variously termed a “thrilling book” and “excellent” in trade reviews, Arsenault writes of the cultural significance of Ms. Anderson’s 1939 clash with the DAR and the subsequent Lincoln Memorial concert. Arsenault’s biography of Arthur Ashe is scheduled for publication in 2012.
All are welcome and encouraged to attend.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing History: The Nasty Girl (Das Schreckliche Madchen, 1989)
event.shortdesc: The Nasty Girl (Das Schreckliche Madchen

fulldesc.p: Shot in an eclectic variety of styles, Michael Verhoeven's Das Schreckliche Madchen presents a fictionalized version of the true story of Anya Rosmus, a German schoolgirl who uncovered inconvenient truths about her hometown's involvement in World War II while researching an essay. "With all its resourcefulness and romp, Michael Verhoeven's ‘The Nasty Girl' is a spunky German cousin of ‘His Girl Friday,' an energetic, black-comic celebration of a gutsy gal news-gatherer and the high cost of digging for truth" (Rita Kempley, Washington Post). The film's ironic tone, innovative structure, and controversial content challenge conventional notions of "History." Nominated for Best Foreign Film. German with English Subtitles.

event.shortdesc: Gil Smart of the Lancaster Sunday News will be speaking on journalism in the digital age.

fulldesc.p:
The digital era continues to rise as newspaper companies are closing doors and new websites are opening their home pages. In response to the impact digital media has had on journalism, the Friends of Ganser Library are hosting "Ink-Stained Wretches in the Digital Age: Journalisms Changes, Challenges and Opportunities," featuring Gil Smart of the Lancaster Sunday News.
The Friends of Ganser's goal is to support Ganser Library by bringing attention to its great resources and enriching atmosphere

event.title: Odyssey of the Mind
event.shortdesc: Students from regional schools will come to Millersville University to compete in Odyssey of the Mind, an international creativity tournament.

fulldesc.p:
Odyssey of the Mind, an international creativity tournament, is welcoming over 425 students from Pennsylvania regional schools to Millersville University. The students along with 125 judges and more than 100 coaches, teachers, families and friends will spend the day preparing for the Odyssey competition. The students work for four months on one of six long-term problems:
- a vehicle-building problem (sponsored by NASA),
- a flight problem,
- a history-related performance problem,
- a structure problem (involving supporting weights with small amounts of balsa wood),
- or one of two theatrical performance problems.

Any clubs, Greek organizations or friends who would would like to organize an activity for the Kindergarten through 12th grade students, please contact Jill Craven at jill.craven@millersville.edu. Activities related to vehicles, flight, history (especially archaeology), physics, teamwork, and theatre are of particular interest.

event.title: Lecture: Dr. Temple Grandin (Moved to Pucillo)
event.shortdesc: Due to expected high attendance the Anna Funk Lockey Lectureship featuring Dr. Temple Grandin has been moved to Pucillo.

fulldesc.p: Dr. Temple Grandin of Boston, Mass., is the speaker for the 2010 Anna Funk Lockey Lecture. Grandin will discuss her lecture "My Experience with Autism." Grandin obtained her B.A. at Franklin Pierce College in 1970. In 1974 she was employed as livestock editor for the Arizona Farmer Ranchman and also worked for Corral Industries on equipment design. She earned her M.S. in animal science at Arizona State University in 1975 for her work on the behavior of cattle in different squeeze chutes. Grandin was awarded her Ph.D in animal science from the University of Illinois in 1989 and is currently a professor at Colorado State University.

Grandin was born in Boston Mass., in 1947 and three years later was diagnosed with autism. Ignoring instruction to institutionalize young Grandin, her mother chose to hire a caregiver to eliminate Grandin's chances of falling into the isolationist shell of autism. With the help of her mentor, Grandin recognized her talents and abilities, allowing her to lead a successful career as a livestock-handling equipment designer. Grandin is the author of The Way I See It: A Personal Look at Autism and Asperger's and has become an influential author and speaker on the subject of autism.

Half the cattle in the U.S. and Canada are handled in equipment Dr. Grandin has designed for meat plants. Grandin has received numerous awards including the Meritorious Achievement Award from the Livestock Conservation Institute, named a Distinguished Alumni at Franklin Pierce College and received an honorary doctorate from McGill University. She has also won prestigious industry awards including the Richard L. Knowlton Award from Meat Marketing and Technology Magazine and the Industry Advancement Award from the American Meat Institute and the Beef Top 40 industry leaders.

Grandin is one of the world's leaders in the design of livestock handling facilities. She has designed livestock facilities throughout the United States and in Canada, Europe, Mexico, Australia, New Zealand and other countries. In North America, almost half of all cattle processing facilities include a center track restrainer system that she designed for meat plants.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Remaking the Future - Promoting Social Cohesion in Northern Ireland
event.shortdesc: Add description here

p.span: On March 16, 2010, Dr. Joanne Hughes, school of education, Queens University Belfast, Northern Ireland, will be speaking on Promoting Social Cohesion in Northern Ireland, at 7:00 p.m. in the MPR, Stayer Hall, Millersville University.

Professor Joanne Hughes was appointed to the School of Education in July 2007. She is from Belfast and holds a BA and PhD in Social Anthropology from Queen’s. She had previously worked in the School of Policy Studies at the University of Ulster. Her main research interests and areas of expertise are community relations policy, inter-group contact theory and the role of education in divided societies. She has published widely on these themes and much of her work has an international comparative focus. Current research projects include: an examination of identity in mixed and segregated districts of Belfast and in other areas of Northern Ireland; an examination of inter-school collaboration in Northern Ireland; an exploration of identity and social attitudes in separate schools in Northern Ireland and Israel; and an exploration of the role of parents in bi-lingual/bi-national schools in Israel/Palestine and integrated schools in Northern Ireland. Professor Hughes has been keen to promote the applied value of her research and she has worked extensively with policy makers, government bodies, community groups and organisations. Her work has informed a major review of community relations policy in Northern Ireland, and she was recently appointed by the Minister of Education to advise on community relations policy in Education. She has also worked with local practitioners to devise and disseminate models of good practice in promoting intergroup relations. In addition to her contribution at local level, Professor Hughes has been involved in a number of international initiatives aimed at sharing peace building experiences in divided societies. Professor Hughes is Director of the Education in Divided Societies research cluster in the School of Education. Research activity within this cluster is concerned broadly with the role that education systems play in reproducing social, economic and political divisions within society as well as their potential for challenging these.

event.title: Reframing Love: Harold and Maude LOCATION CHANGE
event.shortdesc: Film "Harold and Maude" - Location has been changed to Myers Auditorium in McComsey Building

fulldesc.p: Hal Ashby's 1971 black comedy features Bud Cort and Ruth Gordon in a non-traditional love story between a young man obsessed with death and an old woman filled with life. As the tagline puts it, "They were meant to be. But exactly what they were meant to be is not quite clear." Ranked by Entertainment Weekly as the 4th greatest cult film of all time, Ashby's unusual romance challenges existing notions of love, beauty, and the "normal." The late night screening introduction by Outreach Librarian Erin Dorney.
The film, Harold and Maude is sponsored by the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.
This event is free and open to the public

event.shortdesc: University Activities Board presents An Evening with Stephen Lynch, comedic singer and songwriter.

fulldesc.p: Stephen Lynch considers himself a musician trapped in the body of a comedian. His unique blend of musical based comedy has earned him fiercely loyal fans around the world who live to experience his sold-out live shows, four best-selling CDs and DVDs and his top-rated Comedy Central Specials.

Lynch's albums: "A Little Bit Special," "Superhero," and "The Craig Machine," have sold nearly a half million copies around the world. His first DVD, "Live at the El Rey" was certified Gold by RIAA. Stephen has toured with some of the biggest names in comedy, including Lewis Black and the late Mitch Hedberg. He's also headlined his own sold out shows throughout the United States and Europe, where he is considered "the Beyonce of Scandinavia."

event.title: Art Exhibit: Collage Menage
event.shortdesc: "Collage Menage" features 40 Lancaster-area artists representing a collaborative interest of colleagues.

fulldesc.p:
From the French meaning "to glue," collage art unites differing elements on a plane unique to all, thus creating a new whole.
This exhibition, "Collage Menage", represents the collaborative interests of colleagues from the departments of English and History, and from the Women's Studies Program. Dr. Judy Halden-Sullivan initiated "Collage Menage" to support graduate students' studies in her seminar, "Contemporary American Poetry and Poetics." Collage aesthetics inspires the work of many contemporary innovative poets, among them provocative poet and painter, Dr. Thomas Fink, Professor of English at the City University of New York / LaGuardia, who will speak at Millersville University on 31 March at 7:30pm in 210 Hash.
In addition to contextualizing Dr. Fink's visit, "Collage Menage" will feature the work of Prof. Mimi Shapiro, a specialist in book arts and poetry and a Pennsylvania roster artist with "Millersville University: South Central Partners," an Arts-In-Education partnership supported by the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts, housed here at MU.
The exhibit will demonstrate principles at the heart of creativity—the subject of history professor Dr. Tracey Weis's new Women's Studies seminar, "Creativity, Innovation and Gender" (WS 491)--potentially a permanent course in the Women's Studies curriculum. The exhibit will be coordinated by Mr. Ty Clever, director of Millersville's Arts in Education Program.
This exhibition will invite Millersville students and faculty to reflect upon why thinkers choose deliberately to step outside the expectations of traditional forms to juxtapose texts in ways that challenge readers/listeners/viewers with the unexpected. Why take such creative yet dangerous risks? A closing reception on Thursday, 25 March, from 5pm until 7pm, will permit visitors to ask participating artists this very question.
The event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Lecture: Edwidge Danticat
event.shortdesc: Edwidge Danticat from Haiti will speak on her country in wake of the terrible earthquake there.

fulldesc.p: Edwidge Danticat will present the Hazel I. Jackson Lecture. Danticat was born in Haiti in 1969, and was raised by her aunt under the dictatorial Duvalier regime. Her parents left for the U.S. when she was four and was reunited with them and her brother in America when she was twelve. Two years later, Danticat published her first two writings. Several of her books have reached the New York Times national bestseller list.

This event is sponsored by University Theme, Cultural Affairs, Commission on Cultural Diversity, Fredrick Douglass Black Cultural Celebration, African American Studies, and the School of Humanities and Social Sciences.
There are no tickets required for this event.

event.title: Science and Technology Policy Conference
event.shortdesc: The Science and Technology Policy Conference will discuss and inquire about applications for the advancement of human existence and preservation of the planet.

fulldesc.p: The Science and Technology Policy Conference fosters inquiry and dialogue about policy matters related to the appropriate applications of science and technology for the advancement of human existence domestically and globally and the preservation of the planet. Leading federal and state policy proposals will be examined from a variety of perspectives.
The three-day conference will feature an opening session by keynote speaker Ambassador Richard Russell, current managing partner at rpdANALYTICS and CEO at VIAforward.

On day two, March 26, a variety of policy and panel sessions will take place. Topics for these sessions include energy, environment/climate change and cyber security. In addition, Dr. Daniel Schrag, Sturgis Hooper professor of geology and environmental science and engineering at Harvard University, will be the keynote speaker.

Conference attendance is free however, preregistration online is urged as seating capacity is limited. Onsite registration will be available only if space is available. To register or view a detailed schedule of the conference contact the Civic and Community Engagement and Research Project at 717-872-3049 or visit http://www.millersville.edu/ccerp/.

event.title: 3rd Annual Science Olympiad
event.shortdesc: Pennsylvania Central Region Science Olympiad, which focuses on topics such as anatomy, ecology, ornithology, fossils, meteorology and many more.

fulldesc.p:
Millersville University will host the Pennsylvania Central Region Science Olympiad for the third consecutive year. Middle and high schools from 12 counties in the central region of Pennsylvania will be competing against one another for the honor of competing in the state-wide competition at Juniata College.
The Science Olympiad consists of two divisions: division B for middle school students, and division C for high school students. Each division has 23 events, totaling 46 events all together. The events cover topics including anatomy, ecology, ornithology, fossils, environmental chemistry, meteorology and many more.
Science Olympiad is a national nonprofit organization devoted to improving the quality of science education, increasing student interest in science and providing recognition for outstanding achievement in science education by both students and teachers.
For more information, please contact Professor DeCaria at Alex.DeCaria@millersville.edu or ext. 4739.

event.title: Same Sex Marriage: A Civil Debat
event.shortdesc: John Corvino and Glenn Stanton, two of the nation's leading and opposing voices on same-sex marriage will discuss and debate their opposing viewpoints.

fulldesc.p:
Same-sex marriage and civil unions have created heated arguments throughout the past several decades. Is same-sex marriage good for society? Glenn Stanton, same-sex opponent, argues that such marriages would erode the understanding of humanity by treating males or females as optional for the family. John Corvino, same-sex marriage advocate, argues that recognizing same-sex unions would be good not only for gay people, but also for society at large, since society has an interest in promoting happy, stable and loving relationships.
The two gentlemen may disagree on issues but they share a commitment to reasoned dialogue and helping people understand the importance of these issues. Both men strongly agree that controversial issues demand civil discussion, not personal attacks, and so they challenge each other's arguments, never each other's motives.

link.name: Same Sex Marriage: A Civil Debate

event.title: Art Exhibit: "Placeholders" by Hannah Burr
event.shortdesc: Ganser Gallery hosts "Placeholders", an exhibit by Hannah Burr.

fulldesc.p:
Hannah Burr's exhibit is a collection of projects consisting of metaphors in physical items depicting intangible subjects such as relationships, thoughts, interactions, and ideas.
Burr lives and works in Boston, Mass. where she grew up. She received her BA from Brown University in 1995 and has been awarded grants and Fellowships by the Mass Cultural Council, the Berkshire Taconic Foundation and the MacDowell Colony. She's exhibited her work extensively in the New England area, more recently in New York, as well as internationally. Her work is included in the collections of Simmons College, Fidelity Investments, Brown University and the MacDowell Colony. In addition to making installation and drawing, Hannah is an entrepreneurial coach, mediator and educator.
The event is free and open to the public. Gallery hours are Monday - Thursday 12 p.m. - 4:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. - 9:00 p.m.; Friday, 12:00 p.m. - 4:00 p.m.; Sunday, 1:00 p.m. - 4:00 p.m.
Free tours of the exhibition may scheduled by calling Ty Clever, Gallery Director: 717-871-2186. Email: tyler.clever@millersville.edu

event.title: Conference: Disabilities & Public Policy
event.shortdesc: Come join the "Disabilities & Public Policy" forum at Millersville, focusing on the latest news and topics regarding disability policies.

fulldesc.p:
Disabilities and Public Policy: A Community Forum at Millersville University will focus on the impacts of disability policy, disability laws and the disability rights movement.
This event is free and open to the public. It is sponsored by the Millersville University Honors College, Common Reading Project, United Way of Lancaster County, Public Interest Law Center of Philadelphia (PILCOP) and ARC of Pennsylvania.
Speakers for the event include Steve Suroviec, executive director of ARC of Pennsylvania, discussing "Current Issues in Disabilities Policy"; Judith Gran, Esquire, PILCOP, discussing "Disabilities and the Law"; and Thomas K. Gilhool, Esquire, PILCOP discussing "Pennhurst and the Disabilities Rights Movement."

event.title: Opening Reception: Placeholders
event.shortdesc: Opening reception of "Placeholders" by Hannah Burr.

fulldesc.p:
The opening reception of Hannah Burr's exhibit "Placeholders" is an opportunity for Burr to discuss her exhibit and inspiration. "Placeholders" is a collection of projects that fall under the category of metaphors in physical items of intangible subjects such as relationships, thoughts, interactions, and ideas.
Burr lives and works in Boston, Mass. where she grew up. She received her BA from Brown University in 1995 and has been awarded grants and Fellowships by the Mass Cultural Council, the Berkshire Taconic Foundation and the MacDowell Colony. She's exhibited her work extensively in the New England area, more recently in New York, as well as internationally. Her work is included in the collections of Simmons College, Fidelity Investments, Brown University and the MacDowell Colony. In addition to making installation and drawing, Hannah is an entrepreneurial coach, mediator and educator.
The event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Poetry by Dr. Thomas Fink
event.shortdesc: A poetry reading by innovative, collage poet Dr. Thomas Fink of the City University of New York at LaGuardia.

fulldesc.p:
Dr. Thomas Fink, an innovative, collage poet and self-described third-generation New York School poet, will read or, more accurately at times, perform some of his latest verse. Dr. Fink has published six anthologies of poems and two critical studies. He is also a painter, and his work hangs in a number of New York galleries. Energized by non-obvious context building, Dr. Fink's poetry is non-narrative and non-representational. Expect the unexpected!
Dr. Thomas Fink is a professor of English and creative writing at the City University of New York / LaGuardia.
The event is free and open to the public.

fulldesc.p: The master class program at Millersville partners with the Lancaster Symphony Orchestra to bring world-renowned guest musicians to campus to interact with music students.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Humanity: Blade Runner
event.shortdesc: Screening of Ridely Scott's 1982 film, Blade Runner, followed by discussion.

p.span: Blending sci-fi with film noir, director Ridley Scott delivers a philosophically challenging film with superbly crafted visuals. In 2019, a former Blade Runner (an officer assigned to “retire” replicants, played by Harrison Ford) comes back to the force to eliminate a a rebel group who escaped from the off-world colonies to return to Earth.

“The impact of 'Blade Runner' is simply going to be overwhelming, both on the public and on creative people -- and, I believe, on science fiction as a field.” (Science Fiction Author Philip K. Dick)
“The world of ‘Blade Runner’ has undeniably become one of the visual touchstones of modern movies.” (Roger Ebert, Chicago Sun Times).

For more information on the film, see http://bladerunnerthemovie.warnerbros.com/
It’s free and open to the public. Post-screening discussion led by Dr. Greg Seigworth, Professor of Communication Studies, and Dr. Jill Craven, Associate Professor of Film Studies.

fulldesc.p: This concert event will feature the musical talents of Dr. Maria Corley and guest Dr. Frank Kowalsky from Florida State University. The performance is part of the 5th Annual Single Reed Symposium.

Frank Kowalsky has performed as principal clarinetist with orchestras throughout the United States, including the Naples Philharmonic, Tallahassee Symphony Orchestra, and Northwood Orchestra. He has also been a member of the United States Marine Band, the Colorado Philharmonic, the Rochester Philharmonic, and Music at Gretna. event.title: Science, Technology and Me
event.shortdesc: Science, Technology and Me provides girls in grades six through 10 the opportunity to learn more about science and technology-related careers.

fulldesc.p:
Science, Technology and Me (ST&Me) provides girls in grades six through 10 the opportunity to learn more about science and technology-related careers. ST&Me also increases girls' confidence in science and technology, introduces women in science and technology who are positive role models and provides a hands-on approach to learning science and technology. Participants will take part in two different hands-on sessions, allowing them to engage in science and technology fundamentals. Hands-on sessions include topics such as Screen Print: It's on the Bag, Turning a Computer Inside Out and Exploring Biodiversity with GIS.
Registration is underway on a first come, first served basis, limited to 180 girls. The program costs $15 per girl, which includes a T-shirt, lunch, snacks, resources and opportunities to win prizes including an iPod. Parents, chaperones and guardians may join the girls at lunch for a $10 charge or serve solely as chaperones without attending any of the hands-on sessions for no charge.
The program is funded, in part, by grants from the National Science Foundation, Millersville University's Office of Information Technology and the Millersville University Women's Commission. For more information or questions about registration please contact Conni Yoder at 717-872-5783 or yoderconni@aol.com and for questions regarding the program please contact Sharon Brusic at 717-871-5548 or Sharon.Brusic@millersville.edu. The complete registration packet can be downloaded from the events calendar at http://www.millersville.edu/itec.

event.title: Into The Streets
event.shortdesc: Join Volunteer Central by helping nonprofit organizations throughout Lancaster County beautify the Lancaster area.

fulldesc.p: Volunteer Central is calling all students, faculty and staff to join "Into the Streets", a fun day of meaningful volunteer work. Devoted to bettering the Lancaster County area through a combination of efforts by nonprofit organizations, Into the Streets allows volunteers to help paint a room, fix a fence, beautify a city park, tend a flower garden, visit with elderly residents or play games with deisabled children. Help Volunteer Central do their part in working with hundreds of nonprofit organizations by signing up today!
Participants must email their full name and phone number to volunteer.central@millersville.edu by April 5, 2010.

event.shortdesc: Joanne S. Silver will demonstrate how to incorporate the study of World War II into the French language classroom.

fulldesc.p: Joanne S. Silver, Manager of Beach Lloyd Publishers and former teacher of French and Barbara P. Barnett, filmmaker, author, department chair and French teacher at the Agnes Irwin School, will demonstrate how to incorporate the study of World War II into the French language classroom through the use of authentic materials. Participants will become familiar with documentary films and first-person accounts of those who lived through the dark years of Vichy France.

event.shortdesc: The Second Annual Millersville University Public Weather Awareness Day is an afternoon full of celebrating and experiencing everything about the weather.

The Second Annual Millersville University Public Weather Awareness Day is an afternoon full of celebrating and experiencing everything about the weather. This event is designed for children and families, free and open to the general public from 11-3 p.m. on Saturday, April 10 at Pucillo Gymnasium on the campus of Millersville University.
Come produce your own weathercast in front of a green screen, participate in a trivia contest, see hands-on demonstrations, cool weather-related experiments and more. Also, you will have the opportunity to meet and talk with people who make a living by forecasting and watching the weather every day!

event.title: Ecological Art: Creative Approaches to Environmental Challenges
event.shortdesc: Add description here

fulldesc.p:
Lynne Hull, Twist, 1993. A roost for plains raptors.
Annemarie Voss Johnson will be presenting her talk, Ecological Art: Creative Approaches to Environmental Challenges, Tuesday, April 13, at 6:00 p.m., in Myers Auditorium, located in McComsey Hall on Millersville University Campus. The talk is open to all and may be of special interest to those engaged in the life sciences, earth sciences, engineering, art and design and women and gender studies.

Johnson examines the approaches of Lynne Hull and Aviva Rahmani, contemporary artists who create ecologically recuperative works of art. Partnering with scientists and local communities, the artists ensure their work is able to provide practical solutions to environmental challenges. Hull’s wildlife habitat sculptures and Rahmani’s watershed recuperation project serve as models to analyze how contemporary ecological art both reflects and influences cultural attitudes toward the environment. Johnson investigates the artists’ assumption of a housekeeping role for the earth, the connections they perceive between self and place, and the notion of the network as a paradigm for both the healthy ecosystems they seek and the working methods they employ to achieve their goals.
Johnson is a fellow at the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington, D.C., and a doctoral candidate at Rutgers University. She has published essays on the work of artist Jackie Windsor, co-organized the symposium, “The F-Word: Reclaiming Feminism in the Visual Arts,” and co-curated the exhibition, Artists on the Edge: Douglass College and the Rutgers MFA. She has conducted research for several museum exhibitions, including the installation of Judy Chicago’s Dinner Party at the Brooklyn Museum, the Robert Rauschenberg: Combines exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Ecotopia, the 2006 triennial exhibition at the International Center of Photography.

event.title: Diversity According to Family Guy
event.shortdesc: University Activities Board presents "Diversity According to Family Guy and South Park," with Matt Glowacki, entreprenuer, speaker and USA paralympic athlete.

fulldesc.p:
Animated comedies such as "Family Guy" and "South Park" are more likely to teach and reinforce the morals and values of young adults than the homes that they are being raised in. This should not be surprising given that families share less than seven meaningful interactive minutes together in a day while the average high school student and college undergrad spend seven hours a day watching TV.
Television like all things creative, imitates life- and life of late seems to be imitating television. In his presentation, Matt Glowacki explains that, "programs operating on the fringes of societal acceptance often have a more developed, logical, and inclusive view of our society than the entities which seek a strangle hold on morality in our culture."
"Family Guy" & "South Park" are examined anew and mined for gold as Matt identifies the ways in which these programs break down stereotypical attitudes and behavior regarding people's differences. Matt's interpretation of these popular cultural icons educates, but most importantly encourages a fresh look at life around us. Matt's audiences will never be passive television viewers again but rather will ask, "what's the point, what's the moral, and how are they reflective of the goings on of our culture?"

event.title: Performance: Only a Girl
event.shortdesc: LightKeeper Productions Presents "Only a Girl" the true tale of a Holocaust rescuer.

fulldesc.p: The play, "It's Only a Girl", tells the true story of Irene Gut Opdyke, a Holocaust Rescuer who, at the age of 17, helped save hundreds of lives during the Second World War. Based on personal interviews with Irene herself, this remarkable tale of courage and commitment comes to life.

As told through narrative, "visited" memories, film images, and original music and songs, "Only a Girl" carries us back with Irene through her idyllic childhood in pre-war Poland to her days with the Polish Resistance and onward... "Only a Girl" hopes to celebrate the courage and love of Survivor and Rescuer, and to continue Irene's voice...that through hope and love and the shedding of supposed differences...we can find our single humanity. And in that humanity, reach out to one another without fear, only love.
The performance is free and open to the public.

event.title: Sheila Jordan Residency
event.shortdesc: Sheila Jordan Residency

fulldesc.p: Jazz singer Sheila Jordan will be Millersville University's 2010 Artist-in-Residence. Jordan will work closely with faculty and students during her three-day residency on campus from Apr. 19 through Apr. 21. Jordan's activities include holding meetings with music majors for a question and answer session, conducting lectures, discussing her musical career, participating in a music master class and spending time with the Millersville University Jazz Band.

Jordan was raised in poverty in Pennsylvania's coal mining country. She began singing as a child and by her early teens was working semi-professionally in Detroit clubs. Her singing career led her to New York, and she began to encompass jazz liturgies sung in churches.
Jordan's voice set led to remarkable collaborations with bassists Cameran Brown and Harvie Swartz. She has traveled across the globe and released live albums of her perfomances.
Ticket prices are as follows: Free for students, $5 for seniors, $10 for general admission and $20 for club seats.

event.location: Reighard Multipurpose Room, Student Memorial Center

contact.name: Dr. Ruth Benns-Suter, Chair Sheila Jordan Residency Committee

event.shortdesc: Millersville University of Pennsylvania is hosting an open house to honor the James C. Parks Herbarium and Millersville Greenhouses. The event will take place on Monday, April 19, 2010 from 5:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. in the Herbarium, Roddy Hall room 270, on Millersville Universitys campus.

fulldesc.p: Millersville University of Pennsylvania is hosting an open house to honor the James C. Parks Herbarium and Millersville Greenhouses. The event will take place on Monday, April 19, 2010 from 5:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. in the Herbarium, Roddy Hall room 270, on Millersville University’s campus.

The James C. Parks Herbarium is named in honor and memory of its founder Dr. Jim Parks who developed the collection during his 33 years on the biology faculty. At 6 p.m. Dr. Chris Hardy, biology faculty member and keeper of the James C. Parks Herbarium, will present a brief presentation on the “Importance of Herbarium Collections in Biodiversity Research & Conservation.” After Hardy’s presentation, visitors will be able to examine specimens from all over North America in the herbarium. Also, guided tours of the herbarium and the greenhouse facilities will be provided. Light refreshments will be served.

The event is jointly sponsored by Millersville University and PPL Electric Utilities Corporation. The University and the power company have a partnership agreement to cooperate in providing educational opportunities involving environmental science.
This open house is free and open to the public. For more information, contact Dave Zegers by phone at 717-872-3243 or by email at David.Zegers@millersville.edu.

event.location: The Herbarium, Roddy Hall room 270, on Millersville Universitys campus.

event.title: Humanities Film Series - Reframing Autism VIII: Open Panel Discussion on Autism and its Representations
event.shortdesc: Reframing Autism will feature a panel of scholars, filmmakers and members of the autism community to discuss autism and its representations.

fulldesc.p: In this final event to complement the Common Reading Program, scholars, filmmakers, and members of the autism community will discuss autism and its representations.

Participants on the panel include Autism author William Stillman, Dr. Thomas Neuville (Special Ed), Dr. David Hill (Psychology), parent advocate Pat Amos, and Dr. Karena Rush (psychology), and two students to be named later by Dr. Neuville

Stillman is an award-winning writer and author of numerous books about autism including his groundbreaking "Autism and the God Connection" trilogy. As an adult with Asperger's Syndrome, he is a nationally-known consultant and speaker who desires to educate others from an "inside-out" perspective.
This event is sponsored by the Common Reading Program and the Office of the Dean of the School of Humanities and Social Sciences.The film screening is free and open to the public.

event.title: Concert: Sheila Jordan
event.shortdesc: Sheila Jordan in concert with quartet and Millersville University Jazz Band.

fulldesc.p:
Jazz Singer Sheila Jordan was raised in poverty in Pennsylvania's coal mining country. She began singing as a child and by her early teens was working semi-professionally in Detroit clubs. Her singing career led her to New York, and she began to encompass jazz liturgies sung in churches.
Jordan's voice set led to remarkable collaborations with bassists Cameran Brown and Harvie Swartz. She has traveled across the globe and released live albums of her performances.
To watch a preview of Sheila Jordan's Master Class click here
For ticket information, please visit MU Tickets Online or call 717-872-3811.
Ticket prices are as follows: Free for students, $5 for seniors, $10 for general admission and $20 for club seats.

event.title: Undergraduate Commencement Ceremony
event.shortdesc: Undergraduate Commencement Ceremony

fulldesc.p:
The May 2010 commencement ceremony for undergraduate degree candidates will be held Saturday, May 8. The May 8 baccalaureate commencement will be held in Biemesderfer Stadium at 10 a.m. Brian Gladden ‘87, senior vice president and chief financial officer for Dell, Inc., will be the commencement speaker for the baccalaureate ceremony.
Gladden attended Millersville University from 1983 to 1987 and was a three year letter winner as a member of the Marauder football team. He graduated with a bachelor's of science degree in business administration and is currently responsible for all aspects of Dell's finance function including accounting, financial planning and analysis, tax, treasury, audit and investor relations. He is also responsible for Dell's global information systems operations.

In the event of severe inclement weather on May 8, the University may have three separate, successive, baccalaureate commencement exercises. The school of humanities/social sciences ceremony would begin at 10 a.m. followed by the school of science/mathematics at 1:30 p.m., concluding with the school of education at 4 p.m.

Family members attending the undergraduate ceremony on May 8 at Biemesderfer Stadium do not need tickets for general seating. Special needs guests will require a ticket to sit in special needs seating. All undergraduate candidates can request three tickets in the event the undergraduate ceremony is held inside at Pucillo Gymnasium. A live webcast of the ceremony will be broadcast from the Student Memorial Center, where tickets are not required. This site offers convenient access to bathroom facilities, an elevator and refreshments.
For more information regarding the May 2010 commencements please go to Millersville's commencement website at www.millersville.edu/commencement/index.php.

event.title: CyberSafe Partnership Conference
event.shortdesc: CyberSafe Partnership Conference at Millersville University: Bringing national experts, educators, administrators and families together to keep kids safe in a cyber world.

fulldesc.p:
CyberSafe Partnership Conference at Millersville University: Bringing national experts, educators, administrators and families together to keep kids safe in a cyber world.
The conference will feature Special Agent Scott Sutherland of the FBI as the keynote speaker. Sutherland will present on the national perspective on bullying and the global motivation behind it.
Also presenting is educational foundations professor Jon Landis as well as Officer Ted Makauskas from the Lancaster Police and Trooper First Class Tony Thomas from the Pennsylvania State Police.
Landis, Millersville University's expert on adolescent behavior online and internet safety, will speak on, "The psychology of the online adolescent: She's right next to you, why are you texting her?" Makauskas and Thomas will be addressing the developments and complications associated with the law enforcement issues in this area regarding cyber-related concerns.
University faculty and staff, area school district administrators, teachers, counselors and parents are invited to attend. Registration for this event is now closed.

event.title: Denied Authenticity Exhibit
event.shortdesc: A semester-long independent study between Ben Cunningham and Andrew Orloski '10 resulted in an art exhibit at Ganser Library titled "Denied Authenticity."

fulldesc.p: "Denied Authenticity" is the result of an independent study Andrew Orloski had with Ben Cunningham during the Spring 2010 semester. Through our daily debates, we discussed how bothered we are by how casually the media covered the Iraq war. Because of our age difference, our perspectives of the war are quite different. We both have been affected directly by the war and decided to pull from our individual experiences and diverse perspectives to produce work for the exhibition.

Throughout the semester Andrew had been working on "Connections" series that dealt specifically with physical connections and relationships with diverse materials. Ben's work has centered on the critique of society and generating social change through Art.

event.title: An Evening with The Celestial Brass
event.shortdesc: Millersville's Celestial Brass will be performing "An Evening with The Celestial Brass" concert in Steinman Hall, at 42 N. Prince Street.

fulldesc.p: Millersville University of Pennsylvania's Celestial Brass will be performing "An Evening with The Celestial Brass" concert in Steinman Hall, at 42 N. Prince Street, July 16, at 7:30 p.m.

The Celestial Brass has performed at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia and has also had the opportunity to be coached by members of the Rodney Mack Philadelphia Big Brass, Manhattan Brassworld and world-renowned trumpeter, Wynton Marsalis. They will be traveling to Alberta, Canada for the Banff Brass Ensemble Residency July 19-31.
"We hope to share a part of our passion for the music with the audience," said Nate Petley, Celestial Brass trombone player.

The Celestial Brass consists of a tuba, trombone, two trumpets and a french horn. Members of the Celestial Brass include Dan Meeker of York, Pa., Nate Petley of Lebanon, Pa., John Maurer of Upper Darby, Pa., Dan Stauffer of Lebanon, Pa., Tommy Reiger of Hershey, Pa. and will feature soprano Katy Lessie of Douglassville, Pa. All of whom are music majors at Millersville University.
"The Celestial Brass is looking forward to an exciting evening of music making as we prepare for our trip to the Brass Ensemble Residency in Alberta, Canada," said Meeker.

The Banff program offers musicians a great learning experience. It covers topics ranging from concert presentation, preparing for auditions and competitions to marketing and professional management. The musicians will have various opportunities to perform and possibly record a demo CD as a group.
"We are extremely excited for this show and hope we have a good turn out," said Petley.

"An Evening with The Celestial Brass" is free and open to the public. Any donations for their trip to Canada are accepted and appreciated. The performance will include works by Georges Bizet, Edward Elgar, Dave Brubeck and more. It will be held in Steinman Hall, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster. For more information, contact the Celestial Brass at thecelestialbrass.com.

event.location: Steinman Hall, at 42 N. Prince Street

event.title: Einstein: The Practical Bohemian Featuring Ed Metzger
event.shortdesc: Ed Metzger will portray Albert Einstein by presenting another side to the original absent-minded professor.

fulldesc.p: Description: Ed Metzger portrays the original absent-minded professor, confused and troubled father, out-spoken protestor against war, philosopher and womanizer. This show presents the human side of Einstein, who perceived things in a different way than others did before him. Ed Metzger brings out Einstein's sorrows as he was forced out of Germany by Hitler and his horror in learning that his theories were used for the development of the Atomic Bomb. Then there was his twinkling humor, his passion for vanilla ice cream, his Jewish conciousness and his love of music...even though he couldn't "count!"
The performance correlates with this year's common reading, "Einstein's Dreams," by Dr. Alan Lightman.

Bio: Ed Metzger, an accomplished actor and writer, has the unique ability to portray real-life famous people. The most famous of Metzger's portrayals is Albert Einstein . . . with wild hair and all. He is extremely proud that he is the only actor who has ever received an endorsement from the Einstein family who recognized Metzger's talents to personify their relative, the most famous man of the 20th Century.

Metzger's nationally acclaimed portrayal provides insight into Einstein's history through the Holocaust, the Manhattan Project, the Theory of Relativity, his religious beliefs, his personal life and his idiosyncrasies.
Sponsor: The Cultural Affairs Committee

p.strong: The event is free but tickets are required. Tickets can be ordered Monday-Friday, 8 a.m. - 4:30 p.m. at Gerhart Hall (22 E. Frederick St.) or by calling 717-872-3811

event.title: Four Square: A Benefit Concert
event.shortdesc: Twelve hands together play a benefit for Manos Unidas, presented by Millersville University's Music Department.

fulldesc.p: The Millersville University Department of Music presents "Four Square," a four-hand and duo piano concert to benefit Manos Unidas, Sunday, September 12 at 4 p.m.

Manos Unidas, translated from Spanish "hands together," is a Central Pennsylvania organization devoted to helping Hispanic citizens integrate into American culture, while also celebrating and maintaining their own heritage.

Six Millersville faculty and student pianists and guests will comprise three duo teams to perform a dazzling four-hand and duo piano extravaganza, which will be held at Millersville University-Lancaster, at 42 North Prince Street, Lancaster, in Steinman Hall. The three pairs will present highlights from the four-hand and duo piano repertoire of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

This concert is the first event in the 2010-2011 Piano Symposium at Millersville University. Master classes, workshops and concerts will feature internationally acclaimed artists Maurice Hinson, Yuliya Gorenman, Dan Tepfer and Christopher Shih.

Admission is free, but donations to Manos Unidas are encouraged. For more information on the benefit concert, contact the Millersville University Department of Music at 717-872-3357, visit the music department's website, www.millersville.edu/music/ or contact Anita Renfroe, piano professor and director of keyboard studies at Millersville, at 717-871-8859 or Anita.Renfroe@millersville.edu.

event.location: Steinman Hall, Millersville University-Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster, PA

event.title: Autism and Culture: The Emergence of a Diagnosis at Home and Abroad
event.shortdesc: "Autism and Culture: The Emergence of a Diagnosis at Home and Abroad" lecture by Dr. Roy Richard Grinker

fulldesc.p: Dr. Roy Richard Grinker is a cultural anthropologist at George Washington University. When his daughter Isabelle was diagnosed with autism, Dr. Grinker began a long-term interest in and study of autism in the United States and other cultures. He authored the award-winning book Unstrange Minds: Mapping the World of Autism (Basic Books 2007). He has recently begun a multi-year study of autism in South Korea which will be the topic of his public lecture.

This talk is sponsored by the University Theme Committee, the Sociology-Anthropology department, the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences, Global Education and Partnerships, and the Friends of Ganser Library.

link.name: Dr. Roy Richard Grinker - book website
Dr. Roy Richard Grinker - university website

event.title: Constitution Day
event.shortdesc: Come participate in a discussion on the Constitution.

fulldesc.p: Millersville University will be hosting a lecture on Sept. 14, "Constitution Day," in conjunction with the National Constitution Day later in the week. The lecture is free and open to the public.

At Millersville, Constitution Day is part of a larger nation-wide initiative called The American Democracy Project for Civic Engagement (ADP). In the past, it has involved events ranging from informational talks, panel discussions and participatory activities designed to improve students' understanding of the Constitution and the Constitution Day address.
Guest Speaker: Dr. Nivedita Bagchi, specialist in political theory in the government and political affairs department.
Added Bonus: Build your own sundae bar and register for prizes!

event.title: Walk a Mile in Her Shoes Fundraiser at the Barnstormers
event.shortdesc: Fundraiser at the Lancaster Barnstormers game to benefit Walk a Mile in Her Shoes at Millersville University.

fulldesc.p: Millersville University's Elsie S. Shenk Wellness and Women's Program and the Millersville University Police Department are hosting a fundraiser and awareness night for Walk a Mile in Her Shoes, Thursday, September 16 at 6:30 p.m. at the Lancaster Barnstormers baseball game.

Walk a Mile in Her Shoes: The International Men's March to Stop Rape, Sexual Assault and Gender Violence is a project to inform the world of the contributions men are making to stop sexualized violence. It encourages men to walk one mile in women's high-heeled shoes to help understand and appreciate women's experiences and to raise awareness of the importance of involving men in ending gender violence.

Tickets for Millersville's fundraiser and awareness night at the Barnstormers game can be purchased by going online to www.LancasterBarnstormers.com and clicking on the "Fundraising Log-in" button. Click on the group's icon, "Millersville University Women's Wellness Center," and enter the fundraising code "wam." Then click "BUY," select seats and complete the order. Tickets are $10 each and $4 of every ticket will benefit Walk a Mile in Her Shoes at Millersville University.

Representatives from the Walk a Mile in Her Shoes planning committee at Millersville University and from Domestic Violence Services of Lancaster County will be at the event with a table to share information about Walk a Mile in Her Shoes and domestic violence.

Millersville's annual Walk a Mile in Her Shoes event will be held on October 13, 2010. Campus and community involvement in the event is encouraged. A portion of the proceeds benefit Domestic Violence Services of Lancaster County.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Insignificance
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series Presents - Reframing Time: Insignificance

fulldesc.p: Synopsis: "A comedy about life, death, sex and the universe...relatively speaking." Nicolas Roeg's Insignificance remixes the past by focusing on a fictional meeting between "The Professor," Einstein (Michael Emil); Marilyn Monroe (Theresa Russell); Senator Joseph McCarthy (Tony Curtis); and Joe DiMaggio (Gary Busey) in a New York hotel room over the course of one night in 1954. The film uses flashbacks to capture intimate character details that shaped the lives of each of these larger-than-life personalities. During their meeting, Monroe explains the special theory of relativity to Einstein using a model train, a balloon, and a flashlight. This is a dark film, darkly humorous and darkly violent.

Discussant: Dr. Greg Seigworth, Professor of Communication Studies.
Sponsors: The University Theme Committee and the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.

Description:The 2010-2011 Humanities Film Series displays the variety of Millersville University's offerings. The Series features 22 film-related events to complement different areas of interest within the Millersville University community. The two main subseries include: the ReFraming Experience Series (to invite participants to consider ways of reframing the experiences around them by looking at the pivotal films of the 1960s and 1970s); and the ReFraming Time Series (to foster understanding of different ways of experiencing time and to complement the common reading, Einstein's Dreams).

Each film event in the Series is followed by a discussion of the ideas, issues, and challenges that the film experience provides. Discussions are led both by faculty members and students, as well as invited guests.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public. No tickets required.
