event.title: Opening Reception: Karl Hluska Exhibition
event.shortdesc: Opening reception of Karl Hluska's recent work.

fulldesc.p: Description: The opening reception of Karl Hluska's recent work is an opportunity for Hluska to discuss his exhibit and inspiration. The reception and artist talk will take place Thursday, September 23 from 5 - 7 p.m. at Ganser Gallery. Karl Hluska's recent work on paper will be on display in Ganser Gallery from September 1 until October 13.

Bio: Karl Hluska is an artist and educator who works with painting and works on paper as a means of exploration. Recently he relocated to New Mexico from New York City, where he held the position of adjunct assistant professor at the City College of New York.
According to the artist, "My works are threads of engagement where something is created out of nothing. However, they are not empty; instead, each work is an active filter that reflects, encourages and questions the location where I stand. They are always out of reach, but yet physical and present. Their elusiveness keeps the inquiry active, for I am surprised by what is found, and by what is absent."

Ganser Gallery is located on Millersville University, just off the lobby of Ganser Libray. Gallery hours are Monday - Thursday 12 - 4 p.m. and 7 - 9 p.m.; Friday, 12 - 4 p.m.; Sunday, 1 - 4 p.m. All Ganser Gallery Events are free and open to the public.
Free tours of the exhibition may scheduled by calling Ty Clever, gallery director, at 717-781-2186 or by email, at Tyler.Clever@millersville.edu.

event.title: International Film Fest
event.shortdesc: Millersville University Library presents two foreign film screenings. Co-sponsored by the Foreign Languages Department and the MU Cine Club.

fulldesc.p: Millersville University Library is proud to present the 2010 International Film Festival, featuring two foreign film screenings on Friday, September 24 in Meyers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.

"STORM" (Sturm), directed by Hans-Christian Schmid will be screened at 7:00 PM. A 2009 political thriller, "Storm" has received multiple awards, including the Amnesty International Film Prize, Prize of the Guild of German Art House Cinemas, Reader Jury of the "Berliner Morgenpost" and the Bernhard Wicki Film Award.

Film Synopsis: Hannah Maynard, prosecutor at the International Criminal Tribunal in The Hague, is leading a trial against a former commander of the Yugoslavian National Army who is accused of the deportation and later killing of dozens of Bosnian-Muslim civilians. When a key witness commits suicide, it looks like the case will unravel, however Hannah refuses to give in. Hoping to uncover new findings, she travels to the witness' burial in Sarajevo and meets his sister Mira, who she senses has much more to say than she is willing to admit. Despite threats of violence, Mira reluctantly agrees to testify at The Hague. However, she and Hannah must both risk life and limb to make it to the court, only to discover that there are traitors among their own ranks.

"WELCOME", directed by Philippe Lioret will be screened at 9:00 PM. This 2010 drama has also received multiple awards, including the Label Europa Cinemas Award and Ecumenical Prize, European Parliament Lux Prize, Grand Prize for Dramatic Feature and was nominated for 10 Cesar Awards (French Academy Awards) including Best Film, Best Director and Best Breakout Performance.

Film Synopsis: Bilal, a 17-year-old Kurdish refugee has struggled his way through Europe for the last three months trying to reunite with his girlfriend, who recently emigrated to England. But his journey comes to an abrupt halt when he is stopped by authorities in Calais, on the French side of the Channel. Left with no other alternatives, he decides to swim across. Bilal goes to the local swimming pool to train, where he meets Simon, a middle-aged swimming instructor in turmoil over his imminent divorce. Simon agrees to help Bilal, hoping to win back the affection of his wife, who does volunteer work helping immigrants. But what begins as a relationship based on self interest, develops into something much bigger than Simon could ever have imagined, as he too will ultimately risk everything to reach happiness.

This event is presented by the Millersville University Library and co-sponsored by the Foreign Languages Department and the MU Cine Club. Join us for two screenings (one at 7 p.m. and one at 9 p.m.) of foreign films.

p.strong: Both film screenings are free and open to the public, but seating is limited (50 people max due to licensing).

event.title: Documentary: Doing Good Badly
event.shortdesc: "Doing Good Badly" is the first event of the Reflect & Connect series.

fulldesc.p: Description: Dr. Kirsten Bookmiller, professor and director of global education & partnerships at Millersville University, will facilitate the first Reflect & Connect series session with "Doing Good Badly," by Nancy Gibbs (Time Magazine).

The Reflect & Connect Series is a series of gatherings where community members-faculty, students, staff and residents in the larger community-read short pieces of literature on service, reflect on civic engagement and connect with the community. This year-long series features three meetings each semester. Participants are welcome to join individual sessions or attend them all.

Prior to each event, participants register for the session, obtain the reading about civic engagement from Huntington House or through links on Facebook and read a short (2-6 page) piece of literature. At the event, facilitators--faculty, staff or students--organize discussion and activities to help participants reflect on the literature as it relates to service and civic engagement. Towards the end of the event, staff from the Volunteer Central Office discuss opportunities for community service and provide time for participants to sign up for volunteer opportunities that fit their interests.
Reading: Doing Good Badly
Sponsor: This event is sponsored by the Center for Public Scholarship, CCERP.
RSVP:Please RSVP to help plan light refreshments and seating: Reflect.Connect@millersville.edu

p.strong: Sessions are free and open to the public.

event.title: "The Sitting Machine"
event.shortdesc: "The Sitting Machine" - Come see a documentary film about what happens when a teacher frees children to think for themselves.

fulldesc.p:
"The Sitting Machine," A documentary film about what happens when a teacher frees children to think for themselves.
Think beyond the ordinary! Experience learning by doing through the eyes of 10-year-old children in a Lancaster County elementary school. Follow eight fifth graders as they design, build, and test full-size cardboard chairs under the mentorship of their teacher. See how imaginations are sparked, curiosity is fostered, ingenuity is encouraged, and creativity abounds in this local classroom. The experience is sure to inspire educators, students, and parents alike.
Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall
Friday, October 1, 2010

Discussion with The Sitting Machine teacher and the film makers to follow.

This event is sponsored by Millersville University School of Education.

The film will run from 3:30 - 5 p.m. A discussion with "The Sitting Machine" teacher and filmmakers will follow the screening from 5-6 p.m.

Think beyond the ordinary. Experience learning by doing through the eyes of 10-year-old children in a Lancaster County elementary school. Follow eight fifth graders as they design, build and test full-size cardboard chairs under the mentorship of their teacher, Debbie Smith, who graduated from Millersville University. See how imaginations are sparked...curiosity is fostered...ingenuity is encouraged...and creativity abounds in this local classroom. The experience is sure to inspire educators, students and parents alike. The Sitting Machine was a top 10 Audience Favorite at the 2009 Philadelphia Film Festival and Cinefest.

event.title: Congress to Campus
event.shortdesc: Students, local politicians and the public will have the chance to meet and converse with two former members of the United States congress on October 4 from 4-7 p.m.

fulldesc.p: Students, local politicians and the public will have the chance to meet and converse with two former members of the United States congress on October 4 from 4-7 p.m. This opportunity is part of "Pizza, Politics and Policy," which is hosted by Millersville University of Pennsylvania's Civic and Community Engagement and Research Project (CCERP).

Hon. Sue Kelly (R - NY) and Hon. Joan Kelly Horn (D - Missouri) will be on campus participating in an open forum discussion. An informal dinner and roundtable will take place in the Ford Atrium, located in McComsey Hall followed by a question and answer session with the honorary guests. There will also be information tables, including voter registration and giveaways.

Kelly's congressional career recently ended in 2007 after a twelve year term. While serving on New York's Nineteenth Congressional District, she helped balance the budget, reduce taxes and reform federal school spending. Kelly is currently president and CEO of Kelly Consulting LLC, an investment and consulting firm.

Horn served in the 102nd Congress of 1991-93 representing Missouri's 2nd Congressional District. As a member of Congress, she served on the Science and Technology Committee, the Transportation Committee, the Board of the Office of Technology Assessment and on the Select Committee on Children and Youth. Currently, Horn works for the Saint Louis County Department of Human Services focusing on tax and legal services for low income seniors and programs for veterans and youth.

There will be free pizza, salad and a cookie buffet for those who participate. This event is free and open to the public. Registration is appreciated but not mandatory. For more information, please contact Lori Leaman at 717-872-3049 or email her at lori.leaman@millersville.edu.

event.title: For the Record: Guam and World War II and Public Lecture
event.shortdesc: "For the Record: Guam and World War II" film screening and public lecture by Dr. Frances Negron-Muntaner, filmmaker.

fulldesc.p: Description: Film screening of "For the Record: Guam and World War II" and public lecture by Dr. Frances Negron-Muntaner, filmmaker.

For the Record is a one-hour documentary about one of the rare times in American modern history that a foreign power occupied U.S. territory. From 1941 to 1944, Japan occupied the American territory of Guam. This drama tells the story of a 30-year-old Chamorro priest who defied Japanese rule by protecting an American radioman - and the story of how the people of Guam both remained loyal to the United States and struggled for recognition after the war.
This special screening will be accompanied by an introduction and discussion by director Frances Negrón-Muntaner, an award-winning filmmaker, writer and scholar.
Sponsors: Sociology/Anthropology Department, Rosario Caminero Latino Celebration, University Theme Committee, Humanities Film Series, Latino/a Studies

event.title: Humanities Film Series: The Graduate
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series Presents - Reframing the Future: The Graduate

fulldesc.h2: 10/5/10 UPDATE: The location of the film showing has been changed. The film will now be shown in the Roddy Science Center, Room 149.
fulldesc.p: Synopsis: Recent college graduate Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) wants his future to be "different" from his parents' lives, but he is uncertain how to alter it. He spends his time "just drifting" through both life and an affair with an older woman (Ann Bancroft). However, a newly found love (Katherine Ross) inspires him to break free of his parents' upper-middle-class value system to embark on a new, uncertain journey.

Discussant: Dr. Jen Miller, Assistant Professor of Philosophy and Dr. Jill Craven, Associate Professor of Film Studies.
Sponsors: The University Theme Committee and the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.

Description:The 2010-2011 Humanities Film Series displays the variety of Millersville University's offerings. event.title: Iron Chef Cooking Competition
event.shortdesc: Forget the Food Network Channel - come route for the next "Iron Chef" in the first cooking competition on campus!

The event, which will take place in Lehr Dining Room of Gordinier Hall, will feature five student teams, each consisting of four participants, who will prepare an entree to be evaluated by three esteemed judges. Student teams will create their own recipe, which is guaranteed to test their knowledge on nutrition and proper use of kitchen tools and safety. Judges will score each team on taste, nutrition and presentation. A safety judge will score each team on how well they practice proper cooking safety and hygiene.
In addition to cooking, teams will face nutrition questions to test their nutrition IQ. Teams will receive additional points to their score for answering questions correctly.

p.strong: Everyone is invited to come out and route for their favorite team for a fun night of health, nutrition and wellness. Students not participating in the competition are encouraged to attend for their chance at answering nutrition questions and winning prizes.

event.title: Black Marmot in concert with special guest Bern Kelly
event.shortdesc: Black Marmot and Bern Kelly will be performing at Millersville University - Lancaster, 42 N. Prince Street.

fulldesc.p: Black Marmot Bio: The music of Black Marmot is a blend of acoustic folk and rock. With the occasional touch of blues and country, the songs are an appealing mixture of melodic stylings. Upbeat and light-hearted compilations are contrasted starkly with dark fictitious stories. Each song is so unique, drawing from a multitude of musical and lyrical backgrounds, that there is never any repetition; only the constant reinvention of the band.

Bern Kelly Bio: Bern Kelly, considered original acoustic rock, got his first solo record in 2006. After that, he saw two very different paths that could be explored musically and as an artist, so it made sense to make a whole album of them, which he titled "Milemarker" in 2008. His final album, "The Damage," was released in 2009 with the purpose of guitar-driven rock and goal of keeping it loud without ever losing sight of the songs.

Bio: Lonnie Rashied Lynn, Jr. (born March 13, 1972), better known by his stage name Common (previously Common Sense), is an American rapper and actor.

Common debuted in 1992 with the album "Can I Borrow a Dollar?" and maintained a significant underground following into the late 90s, after which he gained notable mainstream success through his work with the Soulquarians. fulldesc.p: Synopsis: The documentary Two Angry Moms documents filmmaker Amy Kalafa and Dr. Susan Rubin's quest to improve the nutritional content of school food. Kalafa crosses the country in search of alternatives to the toxic food environment found in many of our nation's schools. Meanwhile, Dr. Susan Rubin speaks out in Washington and organizes parents in her district. Together they become the Two Angry Moms.
As this film will be shown at the end of National School Lunch Week, parents are encouraged to have lunch with their children at the school cafeteria before attending the film.

event.shortdesc: Concert by the MU Jazz Ensemble, directed by Dr. Keith Wiley, with Guest Artist/Pianist, Dan Tepfer.

fulldesc.p: On Friday, Oct. 15 join the MU Jazz Ensemble under the direction of Keith Wiley for a night of wonderful music with special guest Dan Tepfer.

Dan Tepfer is a New York-based pianist and composer and one of the most formidable jazz musicians on the international stage — hailed as "brilliant" by The Boston Globe, "remarkable" by The Washington Post, a "rugged and emphatic" player by the New York Times, "a new knight of the keys" by BSC News (France). Tepfer has also had the extraordinary privilege of a sustained, ongoing duo partnership with alto saxophonist and jazz luminary Lee Konitz, documented on the acclaimed 2009 Sunnyside CD Duos With Lee ("a benchmark of human potential" JazzInsideNY). His numerous awards include first prize and audience prize at the 2006 Montreux Jazz Festival Solo Piano Competition, first prize at the 2006 East Coast Jazz Festival Competition, and first prize at the 2007 competition of the American Pianists Association.
Don't miss Mr. Tepfer's own set of "Goldberg Variations" as well as solo work with our own jazz ambassadors, the students of the MU Jazz Ensemble!

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Network
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series Presents - Reframing Media:Network

fulldesc.p: Synopsis: In Sidney Lumet's award-winning satire of the media, Howard Beale is "mad as hell" and he isn't "going to take it anymore."

Beale, a network anchorman, has nothing to lose after he is fired for low ratings. So, Beale announces he will kill himself on air during his last two weeks. As he rants against the media machine, he becomes "the mad prophet of the airwaves" and garners ratings the network could only dream of. This satire questions television's construction of cultural and social priorities within our media-dominated society.
Discussants: Dr. Jill Craven, Associate Professor of Film Studies, and Talon Florig, President of the Ciné Club
Sponsors: The University Theme Committee, the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences, and the Ciné Club at Millersville University

Description:The 2010-2011 Humanities Film Series displays the variety of Millersville University's offerings. The Series features 22 film-related events to complement different areas of interest within the Millersville University community. The two main subseries include: the ReFraming Experience Series (to invite participants to consider ways of reframing the experiences around them by looking at the pivotal films of the 1960s and 1970s); and the ReFraming Time Series (to foster understanding of different ways of experiencing time and to complement the common reading, Einstein's Dreams).

Each film event in the Series is followed by a discussion of the ideas, issues, and challenges that the film experience provides. Discussions are led both by faculty members and students, as well as invited guests.

event.title: Carter G. Woodson Lecture
event.shortdesc: Dr. Benjamin S. Carson, Sr. will be giving the Carter G. Woodson Lecture.

fulldesc.p:
Speaker: Dr. Benjamin Carson, professor of neurosurgery, oncology, plastic surgery and pediatrics at the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine.
Bio: Carson became the inaugural recipient of a professorship dedicated in his name in May, 2008. Career highlights include the first separation of craniopagus (Siamese) twins joined at the back of the head in 1987, the first completely successful separation of type-2 vertical craniopagus twins in 1997 in South Africa and the first successful placement of an intrauterine shunt for a hydrocephalic twin.

In 2001, Carson was named by CNN and TIME Magazine as one of the nation's 20 foremost physicians and scientists and was selected by the Library of Congress as one of 89 "Living Legends" on the occasion of its 200th anniversary. He is also the recipient of the 2006 Spingarn Medal which is the highest honor bestowed by the NAACP. In 2008, Carson was presented with the Ford's Theatre Lincoln Medal by President Bush at the White House and was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by the President, the highest civilian honor in the land.

Sponsors: Black Culture Celebration, Black Student Union, NAACP, Millersville University College Chapter, University Theme Committee, Commission on Cultural Diversity and the School of Humanities and Social Sciences.
Transportation: Make sure to get to the bus early to guarantee a seat. Busses will be leaving from the SMC at the following times:
Return shuttles beginning at 9:15 p.m.

This event is free and open to the public.
September. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Michael Morgensen
I Allegro maestoso - Vivo marcato
II Adagio
III Allegro marcato
The Orchestra
MILLERSVILLE UNIVERSITY WIND ENSEMBLE

The Wind Ensemble is comprised of the most experienced instrumental players at Millersville University. Membership is won through competitive audition. This 46 member ensemble performs the finest wind band literature in a chamber setting, and is dedicated to the furtherance of wind band music as one of America's leading art forms. Current officers are Tommy Rieger, President; Hope Greenleaf, Vice President and Carrie Seefeldt, Secretary.

Timothy Mahr is a well-known and highly acclaimed composer, conductor and clinician throughout the United States, Canada, and Norway. He is currently Professor of Music at St. Olaf College, where he conducts the St. Olaf Band and teaches classes in conducting, composition, and music education. He also serves as the conductor of the Minnesota Symphonic Winds and is Past-President of the North Central Division of the College Band Directors National Association. His conducting career began in Milaca, Minnesota, as an Instrumental Music teacher at Milaca High School. He was Director of Bands at the University of Minnesota, Duluth, for ten years and was the founder and conductor of the community-based Twin Ports Wind Ensemble. Mahr graduated from St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minnesota, with a Bachelor of Music Degree in Theory and Composition and a Bachelor of Arts Degree in Music Education. He completed his Masters Degree in Trombone Performance and earned his Doctor of Musical Arts Degree in Instrumental Conducting from the University of Iowa.

Hey! was commissioned by the Anoka High School Concert Band, John Lace, conductor, for its 2001 tour of Norway. Lace asked for a work that would be an effective way to open their program and the composer immediately thought of a long-running shared experience. As old college friends for years they greeted each other or sent messages through students to each other that always begin with "Hey, Mahr" or "Hey, Lace". This work is a piece that says "Hey!" to the audience - it demands attention.

A native and resident of Hagerstown, MD, composer, arranger, conductor and French horn player Michael A. Mogensen (b. 1973) is an alumnus of the music schools of James Madison University and Ithaca College. Mr. Mogensen's works have been presented throughout the world, including performances at the esteemed Music Center at Strathmore, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, and the Midwest International Band and Orchestra Clinic.

"September" was written in lasting memory of those lost during the September 11, 2001 tragedies. It offers a musical journey through the varied emotions and feelings experienced during that heartbreaking time in history. In distinctive writing style, the composer touchingly reminds us "to never forget." The work is nearly through-composed, providing continuous interest and contrasting segments; and included within the chamber sections are solos for euphonium, oboe, and clarinet. Well-crafted and very poignant, this exceptional composition is destined to become part of every wind ensemble's repertoire.

Trittico was composed in 1963 for Dr. William D. Revelli who gave the first performance of the work in the Spring of 1964, in Ann Arbor, with the Symphonic Band of the University of Michigan. The first and third movements are, in several ways, related to one another: their character is brilliantly forward-moving and energetic; the main theme of the first movement reappears in the culmination point of the third movement; and the instrumentation of the movements is identical, with the individual instruments themselves used quite similarly.

The scond movement is a strongly contrasting dramatic scene with turbulent recitatives and expressive woodwind solos, punctuated by low brass and percussion. The emphasis is on the woodwinds and the low brass; cornets and trumpets enter only at the very end with an extremely intense phrase to conclude the movement. The dramatic character is underlined by the strong use of percussion which is extended by a second timpani player.

event.shortdesc: Emmanuel J. Agumah will speak on his life with Buruli Ulcer and how his inspiring story led him on a life path towards helping others with this debilitating, tropical disease.

fulldesc.p: Emmanuel J. Agumah, President, Buruli Ulcer Victims Aid Foundation and Former Buruli Ulcer Patient, will speak on his life with Buruli Ulcer and how his inspiring story led him on a life path towards helping others with this debilitating, tropical disease.

p.span: is a former buruli ulcer patient who spent almost three years (2000 to 2003) at St Martin’s Hospital treating his buruli ulcer disease. Mr. Agumah completed Kumasi Polytechnic with a Higher National Diploma in Accounting last year June 2009. He would like to do his MBA if he gets sponsorship in the near future. Mr. Agumah has written a story book based on his experience with buruli ulcer (My Life and Buruli Ulcer). He got sponsorship from Matuoka Family and friends in the US throughout his education since his family is poor and his father died whiles he was in the hospital. Having known the plight buruli ulcer victims pass through he established BUVA FOUNDATION last year to support buruli ulcer victims and to also help fight this horrible disease. Mr. Agumah is the founder and president to this foundation.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Conrad Nelson Lecture
event.shortdesc: Clarissa Sligh will be the speaker at this years Conrad Nelson Lecture.

fulldesc.p: Description: Photographer Clarissa Sligh will be giving this years Conrad Nelson Lecture on Thursday, October 28 at 7 p.m.
Sligh will be on campus for two days: October 27 and 28. She will conduct a workshop, sit in on several art classes and meet with advanced students during her two days on campus.

Bio: One's life sometimes collides with moments in history, causing it to be altered dramatically by external change. Certainly this was so for Clarissa Thompson Sligh. Sligh was born in Washington, D.C., raised in Arlington, Virginia, lived in Manhattan for 30 years and now resides in Philadelphia. She is currently a faculty member at New York University and the University of Pennsylvania.

Throughout the 1980s and 1990s Sligh wove together the personal and the political in text-based installations, alternative photographic processes and artists' books to open up conversations on contestable themes. Her books include: Reading Dick and Jane With Me and What's Happening With Momma? In 2001, Sligh's installation of photographs and video, Jake In Transition From Female to Male first opened at Visual Studies Workshop, Rochester, New York, and later traveled to the University of Wisconsin, Stevens Point and Woodland Pattern, Milwaukee, Wisconsin. The project continues to travel to universities throughout the United States.
Sponsors: Event funded by MU alum, Conrad Nelson, and a grant from the Academic and Cultural Enrichment committee.

p.strong: The October 28 lecture is free and open to the public.

event.title: University Theatre Presents: The School for Husbands
event.shortdesc: A comic masterpiece by the master of comedy !! THE SCHOOL FOR HUSBANDS An "educational" comedy by Jean Baptiste Moliere A world premiere of the adaptation by Timothy Mooney

fulldesc.p:
What: University Theater Presents: The School for Husbands
A comic masterpiece by the master of comedy! An "educational" comedy by Jean Baptiste Moliere. Adaptation by Timothy Mooney. Directed By Tony Elliot.
Plot: The play features two brothers with different views on how to train the perfect wife. Should she be sheltered and restricted or should she be pampered and encouraged to enjoy life? The men think they are in control, but the real comedy begins when the two young ladies take matters into their own hands. Who is training whom here? Three hundred and fifty years later, the problem is still the same, and the play is even funnier!!
The School for Husbands is produced with special arrangement by Timothy Mooney

event.title: World Language & ESL Conference
event.shortdesc: In-Service Conference for foreign language teachers in its 43 year.

fulldesc.p: Presenters: Drs. Bill and Persida Himmele, professors of Education at Millersville University who will talk about "The Language-Rich Classroom."

Description: The Himmeles will walk you through demonstrations of how to infuse foreign language classrooms with evidence of active participation and cognitive engagement for all students by using interactive "Total Participation Techniques."

The afternoon session will expand on "Total Participation Techniques" with further demonstrations on increasing vocabulary through activities that include movement and interaction for all learners at the same time.
Applications will be made for language learners at the beginning, middle and advanced stages of proficiency.
By the end of the workshop, participants will walk away with a TPT-Bag that will support the simple implementation of Total Participation Techniques with all students in Language-Rich Classrooms.
Registration is required for this event. For more information, please contact the Foreign Language department at ForLang@millersville.edu or by calling 717-872-3526.

event.title: Art Exhibit: John H. Phillips and Carolyn Healy
event.shortdesc: A multimedia installation by John H. Phillips and Carolyn Healy.

fulldesc.p: Description: "Partial Clearing," a multimedia installation by John H. Phillips and Carolyn Healy will run from November 1 through December 10 in Ganser Gallery. On Wednesday, November 3, from 5-7 p.m., the Gallery will host a talk by the artists, followed by a reception.

About the exhibit: The impermanence of objects and people we love; a tint of sadness permeating aesthetic experience; the calming endurance of nature-these are at the root of Partial Clearing. Sculptor Carolyn Healy encourages a sideways glance at beauty, an appreciation of age and wear revealed in the surfaces of humble materials. She has created pathways through metaphors accompanied by media artist John Phillips' projections of slowly changing abstractions and a multi-channel soundscape of percussive bursts combined with quiet aural shadows.

About the artists:John H. Phillips is a sound and video artist. His work has included interactive sound pieces and collaborative sound/sculpture/video installations in museums, alternative spaces and various university art galleries, and has been featured at the International Computer Music Conferences in Ann Arbor and in Beijing, China.

Installation artist Carolyn Healy has created numerous large site-specific installation pieces, some for performance events and many in collaboration with sound and video artist John Phillips. She has exhibited nationally and internationally including Carnegie Mellon University; the Cini Foundation, Venice, Italy; Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia; International Computer Music Conferences in Ann Arbor and in Beijing, China.

Ganser Gallery is located on Millersville University, just off the lobby of the Ganser Libray. Gallery hours are Monday - Thursday 12- 4 p.m. and 7 - 9 p.m.; Friday, 12 - 4 p.m.; Sunday, 1 - 4 p.m. All Ganser Gallery Events are free and open to the public.
Free tours of the exhibition may scheduled by calling Ty Clever, gallery director, at 717-781-2186, or by email at Tyler.Clever@millersville.edu.

event.title: Dr. Elizabeth Guerrero public lecture
event.shortdesc: The Choreography of Nellie Campobello: A Mural in Movement.

fulldesc.p: Description: The Choreography of Nellie Campobello: A Mural in Movement

Bio: Dr. Elizabeth Guerrero has blended her love of dance and Mexican culture in her latest research interest, an intellectual biography of Nellie Campobello, writer, dancer and founder of the Ballet of Mexico City.

Guerrero's interest in Campobello was sparked in a Mexican Revolution capstone course where her students were reading Campobello's short stories about being a girl during the Mexican revolution."She fascinates me because of her literary and dance contributions," Guerrero says. "And she disappeared in her later years."
Guerrero is the 2007-08 recipient of the Presidential Award for Excellence in Teaching at Bucknell University.
Sponsors: Rosario Caminero Latino Celebration, Latino/a Studies

event.title: Brossman Science Lecture
event.shortdesc: "The Physicist as Novelist," a look at the similarities of how scientists and artists view the universe.

fulldesc.p: Description: Dr. Alan Lightman - a theoretical physicist, award-winning novelist and author of Einstein's Dreams - will discuss the similarities of how scientists and artists view the universe. "Einstein's Dreams," is this year's common reading selection at Millersville University.

Bio: Alan Lightman is a novelist, essayist, physicist and educator. Lightman received his AB degree in physics from Princeton University and his PhD in theoretical physics from the California Institute of Technology. During a postdoctoral position in astrophysics at Cornell, he began publishing poetry in small literary magazines. He was an assistant professor of astronomy at Harvard and a research scientist at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics. In 1989, Lightman was appointed professor of science and writing, and senior lecturer in physics, at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In 2001, Lightman cofounded the Graduate Program in Science Writing at MIT. In the same year, he resigned his chair to allow more time for his writing and became an adjunct professor at MIT.
Sponsor: The Mr. and Mrs. William F. Brossman Charitable Foundation, University Theme Committee, and the Common Reading Committee.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Einstein's Big Idea
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Einstein's Big Idea.

fulldesc.p:
Synopsis: Over 100 years ago, Albert Einstein grappled with the implications of his revolutionary special theory of relativity and came to a startling conclusion: mass and energy are one, related by the formula E = mc2. In "Einstein's Big Idea," NOVA dramatizes the remarkable story behind this equation.
Based on David Bodanis's bestselling book E = mc2: A Biography of the World's Most Famous Equation, the program explores the lives of the men and women who helped develop the concepts behind each term in the equation: E for energy; m for mass; c for the speed of light; and 2 for "squared," the multiplication of one number by itself. Like a multi-plot novel building to a climactic scene, "Einstein's Big Idea" traces the stories of a fascinating range of characters, including Einstein, Mileva Maric, Michael Faraday, Antoine-Laurent Lavoisier, James Clerk Maxwell, Emilie du Châtelet, and Lise Meitner. The program also features comments from modern physicists and scientists.
Discussant: Dr. Mike Nolan, professor of physics.
Sponsors: The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences and the Department of Physics.

Description:The 2010-2011 Humanities Film Series displays the variety of Millersville University's offerings. The Series features 22 film-related events to complement different areas of interest within the Millersville University community. The two main subseries include: the ReFraming Experience Series (to invite participants to consider ways of reframing the experiences around them by looking at the pivotal films of the 1960s and 1970s); and the ReFraming Time Series (to foster understanding of different ways of experiencing time and to complement the common reading, Einstein's Dreams).

Each film event in the Series is followed by a discussion of the ideas, issues, and challenges that the film experience provides. Discussions are led both by faculty members and students, as well as invited guests.

event.title: University Theatre Presents: The School for Husbands
event.shortdesc: A comic masterpiece by the master of comedy !! THE SCHOOL FOR HUSBANDS An "educational" comedy by Jean Baptiste Moliere A world premiere of the adaptation by Timothy Mooney

fulldesc.p: What: University Theater Presents: The School for Husbands
A comic masterpiece by the master of comedy! An "educational" comedy by Jean Baptiste Moliere. Adaptations by Timothy Mooney. Directed By Tony Elliot.

Plot: The play features two brothers with different views on how to train the perfect wife. Should she be sheltered and restricted or should she be pampered and encouraged to enjoy life? The men think they are in control, but the real comedy begins when the two young ladies take matters into their own hands. Who is training whom here? Three hundred and fifty years later, the problem is still the same, and the play is even funnier!!
School for Husbands is produced with special arrangements by Timothy Mooney.

event.title: A Woodwind Master Class with Michael Lowenstern
event.shortdesc: The Department of Music presents this master class event.

fulldesc.p: The Department of Music at Millersville University presents: A Woodwind Master Class with Michael Lowenstern, Friday, November 5 at 3 p.m.

Michael Lowenstern, widely considered one of the finest bass clarinetists in the world, has performed, recorded and toured as a soloist and with ensembles of every variety. He has written music for concert, film, dance and various other new media over the span of his 20-year career. Actively involved with technology in sound and music, Lowenstern has been a pioneer in the field of interactive computer music, having created or performed over a hundred works for bass clarinet and electronics.
This masterclass is given as part of the 2010-2011 Woodwind Symposium, sponsored by the Millersviulle University Department of Music.
For details contact Dr. Christy Banks at 717-872-3357.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Dog Day Afternoon
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Dog Day Afternoon

fulldesc.p:
Synopsis: Dog Day Afternoon follows the exploits of two Vietnam veterans Sonny (Al Pacino) and Sal (John Cazale) as they try to hold up a local bank. When the robbery goes awry, Sonny becomes a middle- class hero as he speaks up for the socio-economic challenges facing the lower middle class. As the authorities try to guide Sonny to surrender peacefully to their control, Sonny's chants of "Attica! Attica!" reveal the depth of the lower class's anger toward the repressive state apparatuses designed to keep them down.
Based on a true story, Dog Day Afternoon allows for a little rage against the machine. Dog Day Afternoon vents the frustrations of those held back by the system (by class, sexual orientation, intelligence, or social status). The film's daring documentary look and unusual pacing overturned existing conventions for filming action sequences.
Discussants: Dr. Jill Craven, Associate Professor of Film Studies, and Graduate Students from her Critical Theory Class.
Sponsors: The University Theme Committee and The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.

Description:The 2010-2011 Humanities Film Series displays the variety of Millersville University's offerings. Each film event in the Series is followed by a discussion of the ideas, issues, and challenges that the film experience provides. Discussions are led both by faculty members and students, as well as invited guests.

event.title: Public Lecture: "Power and Gender Inside the Italian Slow Food Movement"
event.shortdesc: A public lecture with Dr. Valeria Siniscalchi.

fulldesc.p: Description: Public Lecture by Dr. Valeria Siniscalchi, cultural anthropologist and Maître de Conférences, Centre Norbert Elias, l'École des Hautes Études en Sciences Sociales (EHESS), Marseille, Monday, November 15, from 4-5:30 p.m. in Roddy Hall, room 261.
Topic: "Power and Gender inside the Italian Slow Food Movement."

This lecture will be based on Siniscalchi's ongoing ethnographic research on the Slow Food organization centered in Bra, Italy. Slow Food is an international organization and movement devoted to promoting "good, clean and fair food." It has more than 100,000 dues-paying members in 130 countries around the globe. Founded by Carlo Petrini and associates in 1989, it has grown to have an international influence due to its membership, powerful media presence and enthusiasm of thousands of volunteers who work to establish school gardens and farmers' markets, promote local culinary culture, hold wine and food tastings, and carry out myriad other activities. It has a strong U.S. presence through Slow Food USA and is on the vanguard of global food activism.

The seminar will include an interactive introduction to Inbound Marketing, Social Media and Blogging for your small business. Learn how to use online tools, such as Facebook, Twitter and blogs to create an effective means of promoting your business and brand. Topics covered will include setting up effective online profiles, creating pages for your business and ways to connect with potential clients and other professionals in your field. Participants will also be given the chance to collaborate and brainstorm ideas for their own particular business situation.

event.title: Lecture: To Catch a Hacker
event.shortdesc: Lecture- To Catch a Hacker: Technologies that bad guys use to catch you, and good guys use to catch them...

fulldesc.p: To Catch a Hacker: Technologies that bad guys use to catch you, and good guys use to catch them...

Advances in technology and innovation have made the Internet a very convenient place for both "good people" and "bad people" (hackers). Online banking, mobile computing, big bandwidth and enormous computing power create a tasty environment for people who want to take your money, your identity and your way of life.
Anonymizers, encryption and fast-flux DNS make it easy for hackers to hide their tracks - it's almost as if the evolution of the Internet took place to accommodate the criminals. This talk will touch on some of the important trends and technologies that bad guys use, and good guys use to catch them, if they can in fact be caught.

event.title: University Theatre Presents: Earth and Sky
event.shortdesc: University Theatre presents: EARTH AND SKY - Murder and mystery, Sex and scandal - A poetic thriller by Douglas Post

fulldesc.p: UNIVERSITY THEATRE PRESENTS: Earth and Sky
A play with Murder & Mystery, Sex and Scandal. A poetic thriller by Douglas Post. Directed By Jeffrey Cartwright. EARTH AND SKY moves fast, but it is a wild ride well worth the taking!

Synopsis: EARTH AND SKY is a cop thriller with devious plot turns, tough and gritty dialogue and enough surprises to keep the most jaded "film noir" fans on the edge of their seats. Chicago has not been kind to Sara until now. She and David, her boyfriend of 10 weeks, are in love and beginning to make plans for a future together. Just when her life seems to be taking a turn for the better, her boyfriend is viciously murdered . The police don't seem to care if they find the killer or not. Well, if the detectives won't dig deeper into the crime and keep on looking, Sara will no matter the consequences!
Earth & Sky is presented by special arrangement with Dramatists Play Service, Inc., New York

Saturday, December 4, 2010, 2:30 p.m. & 7:30 p.m. - MU student ticket prices are $8, general public is $15.
Sunday, December 5, 2010, 3 p.m. - All ticket prices $15.
This event is open to the public. Tickets are required.
Tickets can be purchased Monday-Friday, 8 a.m. - 4:30 p.m. at Gerhart Hall (22 E. Frederick St.) or by calling 717-872-3811 and online at www.MUTicketsOnline.com.

event.title: University Theatre Presents: Earth and Sky
event.shortdesc: University Theatre presents: EARTH AND SKY

fulldesc.p: UNIVERSITY THEATRE PRESENTS: Earth and Sky
A play with Murder & Mystery, Sex and Scandal. A poetic thriller by Douglas Post. Directed By Jeffrey Cartwright. EARTH AND SKY moves fast, but it is a wild ride well worth the taking!

Synopsis: EARTH AND SKY is a cop thriller with devious plot turns, tough and gritty dialogue and enough surprises to keep the most jaded "film noir" fans on the edge of their seats. Chicago has not been kind to Sara until now. She and David, her boyfriend of 10 weeks, are in love and beginning to make plans for a future together. Just when her life seems to be taking a turn for the better, her boyfriend is viciously murdered . The police don't seem to care if they find the killer or not. Well, if the detectives won't dig deeper into the crime and keep on looking, Sara will no matter the consequences!
Earth & Sky is presented by special arrangement with Dramatists Play Service, Inc., New York
Showtimes:
December 3,4,9,10,& 11 at 8:00 PM
December 5, 12 at 2:00 PM
Tickets:
$10.00 General Admission
$7.00 MU ID, Senior Citizens, and Other Students
$5.00 MU ID super saver advance sales only at Gerhart (22 E. Frederick St.)
Tickets can be purchased Mon-Fri, 8:00AM - 4:00PM at Gerhart Hall (22 E. Frederick St.) or by calling 717-872-3811 and online at MU Tickets Online

event.title: Kwanzaa with Dr. Molefi Kete Asante
event.shortdesc: Help Dr. Molefi Kete Asante celebrate Kwanzaa.

fulldesc.p: Description: Celebrate Kwanzaa with Dr. Molefi Kete Asante, professor in the Department of African American Studies at Temple University. The celebration will include a traditional Kwanzaa ceremony and explanation of the history and symbols of Kwanzaa followed by an African feast.

div.p: Bio: Considered by his peers to be one of the most distinguished contemporary scholars, Asante has published 70 books, most notably "African American History: Journey of Liberation," which is used in more than 400 schools throughout North America. Asante has been recognized as one of the ten most widely cited African Americans. He has written more than 400 articles and essays for journals, books and magazines and is the founder of the theory of Afrocentricity. He is the Chair of the United States Commission for FESMAN III, to be held in Dakar, Senegal in 2011, and was elected by the Council of African Intellectuals as the Chair for the Diaspora Intellectuals in support of the United States of Africa. He believes it is not enough to simply "know." One must act to humanize the world.

fulldesc.p: Sponsors: Black Culture Celebration, Black Student Union, NAACP, Millersville University College Chapter, Commission on Cultural Diversity and the African Student Association.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public.

For more information, visit the Commencement website: www.millersville.edu/commencement

event.title: Art Exhibit: Line Bruntse & Lauren Nye
event.shortdesc: "Here, There and the In-between" exhibit by Line Bruntse & Lauren Nye.

fulldesc.p: "Here, Now and the In-between" is a collaborative exhibition by alumnae Lauren Nye and art professor Line Bruntse; based on their residency at the Nyholm Foundation in Denmark, during the summer of 2010. "Here, Now and the In-between" will run from December 20, 2010 until January 27, 2011 in Sykes Gallery, located in Breidenstine Hall. A reception and artist talk will take place Monday, January 24, 2011 at Sykes Gallery.
This event is free and open to the public.
